"It was, says the author, the outcome of a visit to London in 1679, when he enjoyed 'the opportunity of frequent converse with several substantial and judicious gentlemen concerned in the American plantations ...' The most valuable part of the work is a series of letters from the early settlers in New Jersey. 'The Model' was plagiarised by Samuel Smith in his 'History of New Jersey,' 1721, and is quoted by Bancroft; but James Grahame, author of the 'Rise and progress of the United States' (1827) first attached due importance to it ... Copies of original, which are very rare, are in the British Museum, the Edinburgh Advocate's Library, at GÃ¶ttingen, in Harvard College Library, and in the library of the New Jersey Historical Society, and two other are in private hands in America. In some copies a passage (p. 37) recommending religious freedom as an inducement to emigration is modified"--DNB.
Reproductions of originals in the Harvard University Library and Newberry Library.

The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.head: An Account of the Incouragement for promoting a DeÅ¿ign of Planting; in EaÅ¿t-New-JerÅ¿ey, containing the ConÅ¿titutions, and Model of Government of that Province, in a Letter from a Gentleman at Edinburgh, concerned there; to his CorreÅ¿pondent in the Countrey.
div.p: PErceiving by your laÅ¿t DiÅ¿courÅ¿e, that you not only appeared Å¿omewhat reÅ¿olved to be your Å¿elf concerned in promoting the preÅ¿ent DeÅ¿ign of carrying on a Plantation in America, but to endeavour to engage Å¿everal of your Friends in the Å¿ame undertaking, when you found any probability of its taking effect. I find my Å¿elf obliged for your more full Information ãâã let you know at more length the ReaÅ¿ons, inducing me to be Å¿o much concerned in the promo â¢ ing this Affair, Å¿ubmitting very willingly, the grounds prompting me hereto, to your moÅ¿t narrow Å¿crutiny, whether in Å¿o doing I act Rationally or not?

Having at London in the year 1679, the opportunity of frequent converÅ¿e with Å¿everal
SubÅ¿tantial and Judicious Gentlemen, concerned in the American Plantations, I had thereby the opportunity of underÅ¿tanding throughly the great advantage redounding to that City, from Undertakings of this nature, and rational grounds of Conjecture, That their Commerce with that place of the World, hath been one of the greateÅ¿t Improvements of that Trade, they have for many years enjoyed, which hath rendered it now one of the moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable Cities in Europe; the CuÅ¿tomes thereof which in Queen Elizabeths time, were farmed at Fifty thouÅ¿and pounds, paying now in to the Exchequer, near Å¿even hundred thouÅ¿and pounds yearly, which great Improvement may be much attribute to their Trade with America, brought now in a great manner to Perfection, which at that time was but in its Infancy.

From that time I began to have Å¿trong inclinations, to be more fully informed in that Affair, and to be at all imaginable pains, to notice the Å¿ame verie concernedlyâª and for my more full Å¿atisf â¢ ction, I judged i â¢ requiÅ¿it to trace the verie beginnings of all the EngliÅ¿h Plantations, and their gradual progreÅ¿Å¿es ere they arrived at that perfection they preÅ¿ently
are at; I could not reÅ¿t Å¿atisfied with the firÅ¿t Methods I propoÅ¿ed to my Å¿elf, in Order to this, of diÅ¿courÅ¿ing at large with Å¿uch as had been in the Å¿everal Plantations, by putting Å¿uch interrogators to them thereanent, as I judged moÅ¿t proper, for informing my Å¿elf in all things relative to that knowledge, I judged requiÅ¿it for my own clear information, and for being a foundation to a DeÅ¿ign I then began to frame, of being therein my Å¿elf Å¿ome way intereÅ¿ted; And tho I found one and the Å¿ame accompt given me in Solution of the moÅ¿t material QueÅ¿tions I propoÅ¿ed; Yea, from Å¿everal hands, who were Å¿uch, whoÅ¿e knowledge in other things with the good Character they generally went under, obliged me to notice their information as truth without the leaÅ¿t jealouÅ¿ing the verity of the accompt they gave me; yet for my more full Å¿atisfaction, I propoÅ¿ed what I judged would contribute more clearly to my full underÅ¿tanding that affair, to wit, the peruÅ¿al of all the Geographicall deÅ¿criptions of theÅ¿e places in America inhabited by the EngliÅ¿h.

The firÅ¿t thing which offered to my view, in this Å¿earch, was a queÅ¿tion in it Å¿elf, both pleaÅ¿ant and material, What way the continent of America came firÅ¿t to be inhabited after the Flood, it being a World
wholly unknown to the Europeans, AÅ¿iaticks and Africans, till the late diÅ¿covery thereof by Americus VeÅ¿putius, and CriÅ¿tophorus Columbus, Å¿ince by all ci â¢ cumÅ¿tances, it is apparent that it hath been long inhabited: Laetius in his diÅ¿courÅ¿e anent the Original of the Americans, Declaring, That the Spaniards deÅ¿troyed thirty mi â¢ lions of them in theÅ¿e parts of America, uÅ¿urped by them, which is not the 100 part of that continent. And Å¿ince it is by all agreed, that after the Flood, Noah and his three Sons had their habitations in Å¿ome parts of AÅ¿ia; there being no probable evidencies that any of their DeÅ¿cendants led out the firÅ¿t Collonies thither, being Å¿o divided from the reÅ¿t of the World, to wit, from the WeÅ¿tern coaÅ¿t of Europe, and Africa, by the vaÅ¿t Atlantick Ocean, from the North parts of Europe, by the great frozen Seas lying betwixt it and Green-land, appearing to be the Northern CoaÅ¿t of America, from the Northern part of AÅ¿ia, Tartaria and Cathat, by the Fretum Annium, from the FaÅ¿t part of China, and the Philippine IÅ¿lands, by the Oceanus Pacificus, above 2000. Leagues in breadth, and divided from the great lately diÅ¿covered IÅ¿land Delphago,
by the Straits of Magellan; and that IÅ¿land divided again from the uttermoÅ¿t Southern Continent (if any be) by a great Sea not formerly known to the Europeans, and AÅ¿iaticks, being divided from AÅ¿ia and Africa, by the great Indian Ocean, lately diÅ¿covered by De La Mers Navigation; the only probable means of Å¿uch a Migration, being of a far later perfection, than what could anÅ¿wer Å¿uch a population of Å¿o great a continent.

To this apparently difficult queÅ¿tion I find a very Å¿atisfying anÅ¿wer given verie fullie by the Learned Hales, his AÅ¿Å¿ertion, to wit, That notwithÅ¿tanding theÅ¿e apparent difficulties, a Migration unto America from the DeÅ¿cendants of Adam, and Noah, was not onely poÅ¿Å¿ible, but probable, that the Å¿amine was Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ive, that tho the time or manner of theÅ¿e Migrations cannot certainly be defined, yet many of them were long Å¿ince, Å¿ome thouÅ¿and of years; Yet after the univerÅ¿al Deluge, that the means of this TranÅ¿migration of the DeÅ¿cendents of Adam and Noah, from AÅ¿ia unto America, hath been both by Sea and Land. That the readieÅ¿t means of the Migration of Colonies unto the WeÅ¿tern World,
from the EaÅ¿tern, was by the help of Navigation, whereof much might be caÅ¿ual by TempeÅ¿ts, or contrary Winds. But the more Principle from deÅ¿ign, he judging it probable, that the uÅ¿e of Ships was not unknown to the Old World before the Flood, tho not in that perfection that after; But that the Ark of Noah, being an exact piece of Arihitecture, did give a patron for VeÅ¿Å¿els of a greater burden, that from that time the skill of making and navigating Ships had been certainly improved. Heathnish HiÅ¿tories giving us accompt, that Navigation was ancient among the Grecians, eÅ¿peciallie among the Phenicians, Tyrians, and Carthaginians Pliny in his Natural HiÅ¿tory, relating, That the Navigation of the Argonauts to Colchis for the Golden Fleece, happened about 1000. years after the Flood; And that 200. years before that, Danaus Å¿ailed out of Aegypt unto Greece. And tho there be no expreÅ¿s mention of the Pixis Nautica for manie years, after the mention of the uÅ¿e of Navigation, yet the Å¿ame Author relates, That the Phenicians Å¿teered their CourÅ¿e by obÅ¿ervation of the Stars.

But the Sacred Scripture gives a better

Balaam in the time of MoÅ¿es mentions, the Ships of Chittim, or Grecians, as a known thing, Numb. 24.24. In the Reign of Solomon, the Tyrians are noticed as expert Seamen, he having a Navie upon the CoaÅ¿t of the Red-Sea, from thence making Voyages with the Tyrans to Ophir, and TarÅ¿hiÅ¿h, places apparentlie in the EaÅ¿t Indies, thence bringing Gold and other Commodities, 1 Chr: 8.18.9.21.

The HiÅ¿tories of all Å¿ucceeding Ages of the Grecians and PerÅ¿ians, of the Tyrians, Phenicians and Carthaginians, of the Romans, Aegyptians and ChinenÅ¿es; And in the latter times of the Venetians, Sicilians and Rhodians, SpaniÅ¿h, Dutch, French, and EngliÅ¿h, give us a full accompt, how Sedulous and InduÅ¿trious all Maritim CoaÅ¿ts have been in advancing of Navigation in multiplying of Shipping, in Merchandizing and Trading in Å¿earching out and Å¿ubduing Forraign Countries, when either afflicted at home
by war, or otherway â¢
ãâã or growen over populous.

And therefore Å¿ayes the forecited Author, as latter years, hath given us of this Age witneÅ¿s of the TranÅ¿plantations to America, from Spain, France, Portugal, England, Scotland, and Holland, and Å¿ome Ages before that have given inÅ¿tances of TranÅ¿plantations f â¢ om Norway unto Green-land, and IÅ¿eland; So it appears not onely poÅ¿Å¿ible, but probable, that either by CaÅ¿uality or TempeÅ¿t, or by Intention and DeÅ¿ign, either for Lucre of Gold, or for disburthening of the Countries Å¿ur charged with multitudes of Inhabitants, or by greatneÅ¿s of mind, affecting Noble Æ²ndertakings, or by ReaÅ¿on of HardÅ¿hips, OppreÅ¿Å¿ion, and Warrs at home, or by Å¿ome of all theÅ¿e wayes, Å¿everal parts of this great Continent, at Å¿everal times have been planted with Inhabitants, which through proceÅ¿s of time, have multiplied unto theÅ¿e many Nations, and have forgot ther Original, and the Manners, Religions, and CuÅ¿tomes of theÅ¿e People, from whom they deÅ¿cended in AÅ¿ia, Europe, or Africa.

His Judgement is, That the Countries in AÅ¿ia and Europe, which with greateÅ¿t probability, have firÅ¿t Peopled America

Doctor Powels relates, That anno 1170, Madoch one of the Sons of Owen Guineth, went over twice unto the Northern coaÅ¿t of America, and made there a BritiÅ¿h plantation; This is at large proÅ¿ecuted by Laetius in his Å¿econd ObÅ¿ervation.

Grotius hath Å¿ome ObÅ¿ervations touching the Migrations of the Norwegians. Laetius grants, that Iseland, and Å¿ome part of Green-land, were planted by Ericus Rufus, anno 928. that probably from hence Collonies were brought over unto the Northern parts of America, over the Fretum Anian, in reÅ¿pect of the eaÅ¿ineÅ¿s and Å¿hortneÅ¿s of that paÅ¿sage, from Nova Zembla, and the fartheÅ¿t North-eaÅ¿t part of Tartary, over that narrow Sea, and partly by ReaÅ¿on of the congruitie of the Barbarous cuÅ¿toms of the Americans and Scythians.

The SCOTS Proprietors are the Earl of Perth, Lord High Chancellour of SCOTLAND, his Brother, the ViÅ¿count of Metfoord, Secretar of State for this Kingdom, and the ViÅ¿count of Tarbit, Lord RegiÅ¿ter, Five hundred thouÅ¿and Acres, being Å¿even parts of the 24. belongs to theÅ¿e three, and Å¿ome other Gentlemen.

This Province or Collony lyes betwixt 39. and 41. Degrees of Latitude, being about 12. Degrees more to the South, then the City of London. It is in the Å¿ame Climate with the Kingdom of Naples, and Montpelier in France. The Summer is hotter, and longer then in England, and the Winter colder and Å¿horter, the dayes about an hour longer in Winter, and as much Å¿horter in Summer. And extends it Å¿elf in length upon the Sea-coaÅ¿t and alongÅ¿t HudÅ¿ons River, one
hundred EngliÅ¿h myles and upward.

The Å¿cituation of this Countrey is juÅ¿t, as it were, in the Center of the EngliÅ¿h plantations in America, betwixt the South parts of Carolina, which is over hot; and the North parts of Pemaquitte, next New Scotland which are coldeÅ¿t; Å¿o that its conveniencie of Å¿cituation, temperature of the Aire, and fertility of the Soyl is Å¿uch, that there is no leÅ¿s then Å¿even Towns conÅ¿iderable already, (viz.) Shretsburry, Midletonn, Berghen, New-wark, Elizabeth-town, Woobridge, and PiÅ¿cataway, which are well inhabited by a Å¿ober and induÅ¿truous people, who have neceÅ¿Å¿ary proviÅ¿ions for themÅ¿elves and families, and for the comfortable entertainment of Travellers and Strangers.

And the Quit-rents, or Fewes (as they are called) of theÅ¿e Towns and other plantations, already in the Countrey, yeelds to the 24 Proprietors above 500. lib. Å¿terling, yearly Revenue, and the Air of this Collony, is experimentallie found generally to agree well with EngliÅ¿h ConÅ¿titutions, and conÅ¿equently with Ours.

For Navigation it hath theÅ¿e advantages, not onely to be Å¿cituate along the Navigable
parts of HudÅ¿ons River, but lyes alÅ¿o fiftie myles along the Main Sea, and near the mideÅ¿t of this Province is that notted Bay for Å¿hips within Sandy-Hook, very well known, not to be inferiour to any Harbour in America, where Å¿hips not only harbour in greateÅ¿t Å¿torms, but there Ride Å¿afe with all Winds, and Å¿ail in and out thence as well in Winter as Summer. For FiÅ¿hery the Sea-banks are very well Å¿tored with variety of FiÅ¿hes, not only Å¿uch as are profitable for Exportation, but Å¿uch as are fit for Food there; There are Whales, Coad-fiÅ¿h, Colling, and Hake-fiÅ¿h, and large Mackeril, and alÅ¿o many other Å¿orts of Å¿mal Flate-fiÅ¿h; The Bay, alÅ¿o, and HudÅ¿ons River, are plentifully Å¿tored with Sturgeon, and other Scal-fiÅ¿h, Eills, and Shel-fiÅ¿h, as OyÅ¿ters, in abundance.

This Countrey is alÅ¿o plentifully, Å¿upplied with Lively-Å¿prings, Rivolets, Inland-Rivers, and creeks, which fall into the Sea, and HudÅ¿ons-River, in which alÅ¿o there is varietie of FreÅ¿h-fiÅ¿h, and water Fowl.

There are little hills from Rariton-River, which is about the middle of this Province, that go to the verie North-WeÅ¿t-bounds of
it, in which are aboundance of good Mill-Stons to be had, and there is many, both Corn, and Saw-milnes Å¿et, and Å¿etting up already, alÅ¿o on the other Å¿ide of theÅ¿e Mountains, there is brave freÅ¿h Rivolets, fit for Å¿etting of In-Land-Towns, and a great deal of Meadow-ground upon the banks thereof, So that there is abundance of Hay to be had for Fodering of Cattle in the Winter time, and theÅ¿e Meadows Å¿hows the Countrey is not altogether covered with timber.

Its true, the firÅ¿t difficulty meets People in Planting there, is the cutting down Wood (Tho having Å¿ome Meadow intermixt already well covered with Hay, is a great eaÅ¿e) yet the trouble is compenÅ¿ed by the advantage, which the timber being cut down, yeelds, being good Oake, fit for Shipping and MaÅ¿ts; and alÅ¿o CheÅ¿mite. Walnut, Poplar, Cdar, AÅ¿h, Fir; And alÅ¿o, by the fertility of the Soyl, being cleared, which yeelds a vaÅ¿t increaÅ¿e not only of Indean Corn, which is a very wholÅ¿ome Food, but of EngliÅ¿h grain, as Wheat and Barley, whereof it uÅ¿ually yeelds betwixt the 20. and 30th. fold, and with far leÅ¿s labour (the timber being once removed) then in Britan. And to Å¿how the labour of the cutting down the Trees, and clearing the ground, is not Å¿o great as
Å¿ome may Imagine; It is known by experience, that two men arriving there in September, or October, may clear as much ground, as uÅ¿ually brings by HarveÅ¿t following twenty Quarters, that is ahout 40. Scots Bolls of grain.

This Countrey alÅ¿o, produceth good Flax, and Hemp, which they now Å¿pine, and Manufacture into Linnen Cloath, & the very Barrens there (as they are called) are not like moÅ¿t in Britain, but produceth GraÅ¿s fit for Grazing Cattle in Summer time; There is alÅ¿o upon Ground (already cleared) Å¿tore of good EngliÅ¿h Claver GraÅ¿s growing; the Countrey is well Å¿tored with wild Deir; Connies, and wild Fowl of Å¿everal Å¿orts; As Turkeys, Pigeons, Partridges, Plevers, Quaills, wild Swans, and GeeÅ¿e, Ducks in great plenty; It produceth variety of good and delicious Fruits; as Grapes, Plumes, Mulberries, and alÅ¿o Appricocks, Peaches, Pears, Apples, Quinches, Water Millons; which are in England planted in Orchards and Gardens; but grow there with fare leÅ¿s labour; and many more Fruits, which come not to perfection in England, are the more natural product of this Countrey. It is thought Olives would grow well there; and being Å¿tore of
Mulberrie Trees, Silk-worms would do well there; for they were tryed in Virginia, and proved very well, if the lazineÅ¿s of the People, and there being wholly Å¿et upon Tobacco, and the IntereÅ¿t of Merchants, who were afraid it might Å¿poil their Silk-Trade from the Straits, had not hindered.

To Å¿hew how Fruit-Trees do advance in that Countrey, it is credibly reported, that about Burlingtoun, in WeÅ¿t JerÅ¿ey, which is Northernly then the greateÅ¿t part of this Province, from an Apple-tree-Seed in four years, (without grafting) there Å¿prung a tree, that in the fourth year bore Å¿uch a quaintitie of Apples, as yeelded a barrell of Syder.

There is there alÅ¿o, great Å¿tore of HorÅ¿es, Cowes, Hoggs, and Å¿ome Å¿heep, which may be bought at reaÅ¿onable prices with EngliÅ¿h, money, or EngliÅ¿h Commodities, or mans labour; where goods and money are wanting.

p.hi: For Minerals, It is thought there are not wanting of Å¿everal Å¿orts, For there is an Iron-work already Å¿et up, where there is good Iron made; And alÅ¿o, there is diÅ¿covered already abundance of Black-Lead.

div.p: It is exceeding well furniÅ¿hed with Å¿afe, convenient Harbours, for Å¿hipping, which is of great advantage; and affords already for Exportation, great plenty of HorÅ¿es, and alÅ¿o Beef, Pork, PipÅ¿taves, Bread, Flower, White, Barley, Rye, Indian Corn, Butter, and CheeÅ¿e, which they export for Barbadoes, Jamaica, Mevis, and other adjacent IÅ¿lands; As alÅ¿o to Portugal, Spain, and the Canaryes, their Whale Oyl, and Whale-Fins, Beaver, Mink, Racon, and Martine-skins (which this Countrey produces) they tranÅ¿port for England.

The Indian Natives in this Countrey are but few, comparative to the Neighbouring Collony; And theÅ¿e that are there, are Å¿o far from being Formidable, and injurious to the Planters and Inhabitants, that they are really Å¿erviceable and advantagious to them, not only in hunting, and taking the Deer, and all other wild Creatures, and catching of FiÅ¿h, and Fowl fit for food, in their Å¿eaÅ¿ons; But in the killing and deÅ¿troying of Bears, Wolves, Foxes, and other Vermine, whoÅ¿e Skins and Furs they bring the EngliÅ¿h, and Å¿ell them at leÅ¿s price, then the value of the time,
that people muÅ¿t Å¿pend to take them. Like as, that this Collony may be founded in JuÅ¿tice, and without any thing of OppreÅ¿Å¿ion, as all that is already Planted; is is truly PurchaÅ¿ed from the Indians, Å¿o there is a great deal more of the Province cleared by their conÅ¿ent; and all is intended by paction with them to be obtained; Å¿o that whoever PurchaÅ¿e; or Plant under the Proprietors; Å¿hal be fred of that incumbrance; and if there were any hazard from the Indians as really there is none; yet this Province could hardly be in any danger; In reÅ¿pect that to the North, upon the Main-Land; from whence the hazard; if any muÅ¿t come; the Province of New-York comes betwixt it and them, and 20. miles and more, above upon HudÅ¿ons River, there is a Fort called New-Albany.

There were ConÅ¿titutions of Government made by the Lord Barkley, and Sir George Cartwright, in which Å¿uch proviÅ¿ion was made, both for Liberty of Religion, and Propertie, that the Province hath been conÅ¿iderably Peopled and many reÅ¿orted there from the Neighbouring Collonies, Å¿o that the Planters are able already to MuÅ¿ter 500. well Armed Men.

they hold not themÅ¿elves in conÅ¿cience obliged, for Religions Å¿ake, to make an alteration, or to endeavour to turn out their partners, in the Government, becauÅ¿e they differ in Opinion from them, and this is no more then to follow that great Rule, To do as they would be done by.

TheÅ¿e are the Fundamentals, which are not alterable by any Act of the great Council, as other things, by the voices of 2 thirds, but only by an univerÅ¿al agreement; Å¿o it is hoped, that this hint will Å¿atisfie all Å¿ober and underÅ¿tanding people, what Encouragement Å¿uch a Government may give.

For Husband-men that hes a Stock, able to tranÅ¿port themÅ¿elves and Families, with a few Servants, and to have but a 100. pound Scots, or a 100. Merks more, to carry over in Commodities, they Å¿hall have upon their arrivall 100 Acres of good ground, meaÅ¿ured out to them, or above, not exceeding 500. Acres: And for their encouragement, Å¿hall for the firÅ¿t 7. years pay nothing, and then have what they pleaÅ¿e, not under 100. nor exceeding 500. Acres, confirmed to them, and their heirs for ever, paying half a Crown an Acre, never to be raiÅ¿ed upon them: And
for the Charge of the firÅ¿t year, they may eaÅ¿ily Calculate, carrying over as much Oat-meal, as will Å¿erve them Bread, and the fraught will be inconÅ¿iderable, and they will get fleÅ¿h enough in the Countrey for killing, without charge, and will be able to clear more ground the firÅ¿t winter, then willâª double Å¿erve their Families after the firÅ¿t harveÅ¿t, Å¿o that they will only have to buy with the Commodities they carry over with them, Seed, and BeaÅ¿ts.

The Charge of tranÅ¿portation, is, for every Man or Woman 5. lib. Å¿tarling, paÅ¿Å¿age and intertainment, for children under 10. years of age, 50. Å¿hilling, and Sucking children nothing, 40. Å¿hillings for the tunn of goods, and often under.

The Voyage is judged leÅ¿Å¿e Sea hazard then either to Holland, or London, and if there be any tollerable winds, it is eaÅ¿ily made in 6. weeks, There went a Å¿hip laÅ¿t harveÅ¿t to WeÅ¿t JerÅ¿ey, from the Road of Aberden: and they came to Delaware-River-mouth in 8. weeks, though they had great Calmes, and of betwixt 30. and 40. PaÅ¿sengers that went out of Aberdeen Å¿everal women, and children, not above 4. of them had been at Sea before, not one dyed, nor was Å¿ick by the way.

For Ordinary Å¿ervants, who are willing to go over, after 4. Years Å¿ervice from the time of there arryvall there, during which time they Å¿hall be well entertained in meat and cloathing) they Å¿hall have Å¿et out to each 25. Acres to them and theirs for ever, paying 2. pence an Acre, as much Corn as will Å¿ow an Acre, and a Sute of now cloaths; Now, ConÅ¿idering that there is 5. pound Sterling payed for their PaÅ¿Å¿age, this is good termes; and that after the terme of their Service is expired, they will gain more in one year there, then they can do in two at home, towards the gaining of a Stock to their land, and it may be eaÅ¿ily conceived that they will be well treated by their MaÅ¿ters, Å¿ince it is their IntereÅ¿t to do Å¿o there more then here, for that they would be ConÅ¿iderable LoÅ¿ers, either by their Death, or Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, being out Å¿o great an advance for them, if, by any hard-Å¿hip, they Å¿hall be diÅ¿abled to Å¿erve out their times.

All Sorts of TradeÅ¿men may make a brave Livelyhood there, Å¿uch as Carpenters, Ship-wrights, Rope-makers, Smiths, Brick-makers, Taylors, Tanners, Cowpers, Mill-wrights, Joyners; Shooemakers, &c. and any Å¿uch like, who are
willing to go Å¿erve the four years, not having to tranÅ¿port themÅ¿elves, Å¿hall in conÅ¿ideration of their Trade, have (after the expiring of their Service) 30. Acres, 2. pence the Acre, as much Corn as well Å¿ow 2. Acres, a cow and a Sow: And for the incouragement of any Å¿uch TraÅ¿dmen, who are willing to go over and tranÅ¿port themÅ¿elves, they Å¿hall have the like quantitie of Land, at the Å¿ame rent, and the Proprietors will oblidge themÅ¿elves to find them work for a year, after their arryval, at as good Rates as they can have here, untill they furniÅ¿h themÅ¿elves with Å¿ome Stock to make better advantage upon the Place.

We will not encourage any to go there in expectation of Gold and Silver mines; yea, tho there were Å¿uch in the Countrey, we Å¿hould not be curious nor induÅ¿trous to Å¿eek them out: being beÅ¿ides the Toyl, and Labour, but occaÅ¿ions envy, and Emulation: Nor yet is their Suggar or Indigo there, or Cotton, nor any Å¿tore of Tobacco, tho it grows there very well. But We conÅ¿ider it not our intereÅ¿t to imploy much ground on it; The Riches of this Countrey ConÅ¿iÅ¿ts in that which is moÅ¿t SubÅ¿tantial and neceÅ¿Å¿ar for the uÅ¿e of men, to wit, Plenty of Corn and Cattle (and they have
beÅ¿ides Vines, and Fruits in abundance, as before has been Å¿aid) Å¿o that who dwell here, need not to be oblidged to any other Plantation, for any thing neceÅ¿Å¿ar for Life; and all other Plantations are beholden to them for neceÅ¿Å¿aries, without which, their other CurioÅ¿ities would little avail them: This with the Province of New-York, being the Granary or Store-houÅ¿e of the WeÅ¿t-Indies, without which Barbadoes and the Leewards IÅ¿landsâª could not Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t; Yea, New-England is forced to come there every year for Corn, this, with the advantage of FiÅ¿hery, being conÅ¿idered, will eaÅ¿ily induce Sober and induÅ¿trious People, to prefer a Plantation here to moÅ¿t other places.

body.p:
I deÅ¿ire Sir, you may here Å¿top a little, and conÅ¿ider the Incouragment to be had from the above written Information, which will by any underÅ¿tanding PerÅ¿on be judged of very great import, you come not to a place altogether void of Inhabitants; But on the contrar to a Countrey, where at your firÅ¿t landing you have houÅ¿es, which can accommodat you with all neceÅ¿sars whatÅ¿oever: If you look back with me to the great trouble theÅ¿e were redacted to, who firÅ¿t went to that place of the World,
who were neceÅ¿Å¿itat to carry over with them, HorÅ¿es, Cows, Sheep, Hoggs, &c. Yea, all Å¿orts of proviÅ¿ions, you will certainly acknowledge that it is a very eaÅ¿ie buÅ¿ineÅ¿s now, in compariÅ¿on of what it was then, when Å¿o Å¿oon as you come to land, you have houÅ¿es to affoord you good and comfortable accommodation, till you make proviÅ¿ion for one of your own; when you have Å¿ome way accommodat your Å¿elf with Lodging, you may from all hands provide your Å¿elf with HorÅ¿es, Cows, Sheep, Hoggs, &c. all Å¿orts of Poultry, all Å¿orts of Seed for Å¿owing, this conÅ¿ideration does in my apprehenÅ¿ion, make the DeÅ¿ign far more eaÅ¿ie, then would appear at firÅ¿t to any who would be neceÅ¿Å¿itat to lay before his eyes great difficulties to be rancountered, when come from Ships, lodging is wanting upon the Å¿hore, no other Victuals are in readineÅ¿s but what is brought along from the place they came from, none of theÅ¿e other accommodations to be furniÅ¿hed, but what is brought a great way off: Sir, you will be oblidged to Å¿ay we have even upon this one conÅ¿ideration, a great advantage of our Countrey-men lately Å¿ettled at Port-Royal in Carolina, to mention nothing elÅ¿e in this place.

But now let us return to the peruÅ¿al of Å¿everal
Letters from that place, and I deÅ¿ire you to mark narrowly if you obÅ¿erve the leaÅ¿t contradiction in any matterial point, contained in any of them, or if you do not find the above written DiÅ¿cription quadrat in the leaÅ¿t particular with the Å¿aid Letters.

div.head: A Letter from Thomas Rudyard Deputy Governour of New-EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, to a Friend at London, dated at EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey the 30th. of the 3d. Moneth called May, 1683.
div.p: TO be as particular in my return, were but thy due, yet I cannot promiÅ¿e Å¿o much, However I may give thee Å¿ome general account of the Province, and of our Å¿atisfaction with our preÅ¿ent Lot, the Å¿hort time I have experienced this.

But to give thee alÅ¿o, as thou deÅ¿ires a Character of PenÅ¿alvania and WeÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey; that will be a task I muÅ¿t be excuÅ¿ed to undertake, leaÅ¿t I give offence, or at leaÅ¿t bring me under cenÅ¿ure as partial: Were
I not concerned in any of the Provinces I might Å¿atisfie thy curioÅ¿itie: But being chieflie intereÅ¿ted in this, I'le be very cautious medling with my Neighbours more then here, one with another, Å¿o I may uÅ¿e my freedom with my Neighbours which they take not ill, but writ that they may take otherwayes; They lye Å¿o near adjacent, that they may be Å¿aid in a Å¿ence, to be but one Countrey; And whats Å¿aid for one in General may Å¿erve for all: I have been at Burlingtoun, and at PenÅ¿ilvania, as far as Philadelphia, which lyes about 20, miles below Burlingtoun: That journey by Land gave me Å¿ome view of all the Provinces, and made me now conÅ¿iderably to eÅ¿timate this of EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey; having Å¿ome Conveniences eÅ¿teemed be me, which the others are not Å¿o plentifully furniÅ¿hed withal, viz. freÅ¿h and Å¿alt Meadows, which now are very valuable and no man here will take up a Tract of Land without them; being the Å¿upport of their flocks in Winter, which other parts muÅ¿t Å¿upplie be Å¿tore, and taking more care for EngliÅ¿h GraÅ¿s; But know where Å¿alt MarisÅ¿hes are not; there is no Muskettos,
and that manner of Land, the more health, and this was often anÅ¿wered me, when I have been making compariÅ¿ons; I muÅ¿t tell thee, their Character in Print by all that reads it, here is Å¿aid to be modeÅ¿t, and much more might have been Å¿aid in its Commendation. We have one thing more particular to us, which the other want alÅ¿o: which is vaÅ¿t OyÅ¿ters banks, which is ConÅ¿tant freÅ¿h Victuals during the winter to EngliÅ¿h as well as Indians; of theÅ¿e there are many all along our CoaÅ¿ts from that Sea as high as againÅ¿t New York, whence they come to fetch them, Å¿o we are Å¿upplied with Å¿alt fiÅ¿h at our doors, or within half a tydes paÅ¿Å¿age, and freÅ¿h FiÅ¿h in aboundance in every little brook, as Pearch, Trout, Ells, &c. which we catch at our doors. ProviÅ¿ions here are very plentiful, and people generally well Å¿tockt with Cattle: New-York and Burlingtoun hath hitherto been their Mercat, Few or no Trading-Men being here in this Province, I believe it hath been very unhappily heretofore under an ill managed Government, and moÅ¿t of
the people who are Å¿uch, who have been invited from the adjacent Collonies by that goodneÅ¿s of its Soill, and convenient Scituation, at Amboy we are now building Å¿ome Å¿mall houÅ¿es of 30. foot long, and 18. foot breadth, fitting to entertain Work-men, and Å¿uch who will go and build larger, the Å¿tones lye exceeding well and good up that Rariton River a Tydes paÅ¿Å¿age, and OyÅ¿ter-Å¿hells upon the point to make lyme withall, which will wonderfully accommodat us in building good houÅ¿es cheap, warm for Winter, cool for Summer, and durable, covering for houÅ¿es are Shingles, Oak, CheÅ¿nut and Cedar, we have plentiful here of all, the laÅ¿t endures a mans age if he live to be old; There is 5. or 6. Sawmills going up here this Spring, two at work already, which abates the price of boords half in half, and all other timber for building, for although timber coaÅ¿t nothing; yet workmanÅ¿hip by hand was London price, or near upon, or Å¿ometimes more, which theÅ¿e Mills abate; we buy Oak and CheÅ¿nut boords no cheaper then laÅ¿t year; My habitation with Samuell Groome is at Elizabeth
Town, and here we came firÅ¿t, it lyes on a freÅ¿h Å¿mall river, with the tyde, Ships of 30. or 40. Tuns come before our doors, throughout this Town is good EngliÅ¿h graÅ¿s and (bears) a very good burthen; we cannot call our habitation Å¿olitarie, for what with the publict employ I have little leÅ¿s companie at my houÅ¿e dayly then I had in George Yeard, although not Å¿o many paÅ¿s by my doors. The people are general a Å¿ober profeÅ¿Å¿ing people, WiÅ¿e in their Generation, Courtious in their Behaviour, and ReÅ¿pectful to us in Office among them. As for the Temperature of the Air, it is wonderfully Å¿cituated to the Humours of Mankind, the wind and weather rarely holding in one point, or one kind for ten dayes together: It is a rare thing for a VeÅ¿Å¿el to be wind-bound for a week together, the wind Å¿eldom holding in a point more then 48. hours, & in a Å¿hort time we have weet and dry, warm and cold weather, which changes we often deÅ¿ire in England and look for before they come; Yet this Variation creats not cold, nor have we the tenth part of the cold as we have in England; I never had any Å¿ince I came,
and in the midÅ¿t of Winter, and FroÅ¿ts could endure it with leÅ¿s cloaths then in England, for generally I go with that Å¿ame Cloaths I uÅ¿e to wear in Summer with you, but warm cloaths hurt not. I bleÅ¿s the LORD, I never had better health nor my Family, my Daughters are very well improved in that reÅ¿pect, and tell me, they would not change their place for George Yeard, nor would I; People here are generally Å¿ettled, where the tyde reaches, and althoughs this is good Land and well Timbered and plentifully Å¿upplied with Salt-MariÅ¿h, yet there is much better Land up higher on the River, where they may go up with Å¿mall boats, where many now are Å¿ettling, there's extraordinary Land, freÅ¿h Meadows overflowed in the Winter time, that produces multitudes of Winter Corns, and its believed will end are 20, 30, or 50, years flowing without intromiÅ¿Å¿ion, and not decay; Å¿uch Land there is at Sops on HudÅ¿ons River, which hath born Winter Corn about 20. years without help, and is as good as at firÅ¿t, and better. William Penn took a view of the Land this laÅ¿t moneth, when here,
and Å¿aid, he had never Å¿een Å¿uch before in his life: All the EngliÅ¿h Merchants, and many of the Dutch have taken, and are deÅ¿irous to take up Plantations with us. Our Countrey here called Berghen is almoÅ¿t Dutchmen, at a town called Newark 7. or 8. miles hence is made great quantities of Syder, exceeding any we can have from New-England, or Rood-IÅ¿land, or Long-IÅ¿land; I hope to make 20. or 30. Barrels out of our Orchard next year, as they have done who had it before me, for that, it muÅ¿t be as providence ordered: Upon our view and Å¿urvey of Amboy-point we find extraordinary well Å¿cituate for a great Town or City, beyound expectation, at low water round about the point are OyÅ¿ters; There are OyÅ¿ters of two kinds, Å¿mall as EngliÅ¿h, and others two or three morÅ¿ells, exceeding good for roaÅ¿ting and Å¿tewing; The people Å¿ay our OyÅ¿ters are good and in Å¿eaÅ¿on all Summer; The firÅ¿t of the third Moneth I eat of them at Amboy very good; The point is good lively Land, 10. Å¿ome places 20. foot above the water mark, About it are Å¿everal Coves with Å¿mall CoaÅ¿ts may lay up VeÅ¿Å¿els as
in a decke, beÅ¿ides great Ships of any burthen, may all ryde before the town Land-loked againÅ¿t all winds: There Rariton-River runs up, or rather down 50 (far larger,) Å¿ome Å¿ay 100. mylles for Å¿mall boats. I Å¿aw Å¿everal vines upon the point, which produces, as they Å¿ay, good grapes in their SeaÅ¿on, this Countrie is very full of them, but being no preÅ¿ent mother of profite, few regard them more then to pick them as they lay in their way when they are rype. We have Å¿tore of Clamms eÅ¿teemed much better then OyÅ¿ters; one FeÅ¿tivals the Indians feaÅ¿t with them, there are Shallops, but in no great plentie. FiÅ¿h we have great Å¿tore, as our relation Å¿et forth, but they are very good when catcht. (as the proverb is) I have Å¿everal Barrels by me now, which are good for our Table, and for Sale. I brought a Sea-Net over with me which may turn to good account. Sea-Nets are good MerchandiÅ¿e here, mine coÅ¿t me about 4. or 5. lib. and can have 20. lib. for it if I would Å¿ell it now; I may writ of many Å¿uch matters in our Province, which may invite perÅ¿ons here,
but Å¿o am reÅ¿olved to conclude, knowing that in probability, there is not an InduÅ¿trious man, but by GODS bleÅ¿Å¿ing may not only have a comfortable, but plentifull Å¿upplie of all things neceÅ¿Å¿ary for this life, with the Å¿alutation of my true affection to all, &c. I reÅ¿t thy affectionat friend,

div.head: A Letter from Samuell Groome Surveyour General in EaÅ¿t-New-JerÅ¿ey, dated at EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, the 11th. of AuguÅ¿t, 1683.
div.p:
SInce my laÅ¿t I have now Å¿ounded the Channell from Amboy to Sandyhook, and finds it to be a broad and bold Channell in no place leÅ¿s then 3. fathom at high water, in ordinary tydes 4, 5, or 6, fathom, except in one Å¿hort place, Rariton River is a good River, and hath a good tyde of flood, overpowering the freÅ¿hes about 30: miles above Amboy, after its flood, the tyde hath no force againÅ¿t the FreÅ¿hes, which comes out of Å¿everal branches of Rariton, and joyns in one, 40. or 50. miles above Amboy,
I have Å¿pent a conÅ¿iderable time in making diÅ¿covery, I have not as yet had times to lay out much land for you, only about 17. or 18. thouÅ¿and Acres in one tract, good upland near Elizabeth Town; I have now Å¿een the tract of Land againÅ¿t (or nigh Amboy point formerly laid out by Vanquillian; it is on the WeÅ¿t-Å¿ide of a Creek called Chingeroces, about eight thouÅ¿and Acres. And I intend Å¿hortly to lay as much or twice as much more to it; but firÅ¿t we muÅ¿t talk with the Natives about that, and other tracts of Land they are not yet paid for; The laÅ¿t day of this moneth is appointed to treat with Å¿everal Indians to buy Å¿everal exceeding good tracts nigh the head of Rariton.

The tenth of the next Moneth is alÅ¿o appointed to treat with other Indians, to buy other tracts of choice Meadowing, and Æ²p-land that lyeth about 12. or thirteen myles up into the Countrey, which I have Å¿een; and when we have accompliÅ¿hed theÅ¿e two things, we Å¿hall he able to lay out for you much land; and when I have been up in the Countrey towards and at Barnagate, and agreed with the Indians thereabout, for Å¿uch land as we may Å¿ee occaÅ¿ion to purchaÅ¿e (preÅ¿ently) in order to a Å¿etlement
there; for here are many both of New-England, New-York, and Å¿ome parts of this Province, Å¿tands ready to Å¿it down in that part of the Countrey, not only for the Å¿ake of the good Æ²p land and Meadows, which report Å¿aith, is much thereabouts; but alÅ¿o for the Å¿ake of the Whale Trade, and other fiÅ¿hing trade, which is like to be there Å¿hortly. New-England Men, and others were a â¢ tampering with the Indians to have purchaÅ¿ed there, before and Å¿ince we came, but now they are out of hopes of coming in at that door; Å¿o now they make their AddreÅ¿ses to us, and would have us to purchaÅ¿e, and let them come in our Tennents, otherwayes as we may agree. I intend to attempt theÅ¿e things, this fall I have not been much on the South Å¿ide of Rariton, only upon Å¿ome upland at Å¿everall places, and upon the tract of 8. thouÅ¿and 3. hundreth and 20. Acres of yours aforementioned; and alÅ¿o on the Meadowing that lyes on the Å¿outhÅ¿ide of Rariton above Amboy, a year or two Å¿ince, purchaÅ¿ed of the Indians in the name of Dam Cartwright, though it was never intended for her, nor for any Proprietor, but as it fell out, they quarrelled about diÅ¿poÅ¿ing and Å¿haring thereof, Å¿o it is now without controverÅ¿ie yours: Now know that Rariton River is
accommodate on both Å¿ides with Å¿alt and freÅ¿h meadows, Å¿alt as far as the Å¿alt Å¿ea water flows or predominats, and freÅ¿h above as the River of Thames. We have about 3000. Acres of meadowing butting on the river, I hope it will never hurt Amboy town, beÅ¿ides report Å¿aith, that the upland next adjoyning to this meadowing, beginning over againÅ¿t Amboy, and Å¿o up 10, or 12, miles to a River that Å¿tricks out of Rariton Å¿outh, and is called South River, is but mean land.

It may be well if you would agree to take each one a 24th part of Lands as we lay them out whither it be more or leÅ¿s, or elÅ¿e take 500. Acres Lots, and let theÅ¿e Lots be caÅ¿t when 24. times 500 Acres is laid out, & where we can make greater Lots we may; we have now got up three houÅ¿es at Amboy, and three more ready to be Å¿et up, but workmen are Å¿carce, and many of them baÅ¿e; the beÅ¿t will work but when they can Å¿pare time out of their plantations, (if no help comes it will be long are Amboy be built, as London is) houÅ¿ing will bring a Trade to that place, the Indians comes thither to get FiÅ¿h, Foul, OyÅ¿ters, Clams, MuÅ¿Å¿els, &c. (as people go to mercat for things they want) and theÅ¿e Indians
brings at SeaÅ¿ons great quantities of skins down Rariton, Å¿o by Amboy and to New-York, where they have a continuall Å¿upplie of things they want.

Well here is a brave Countrey, the ground very fruitfull, and wonderfull inclinable to EngliÅ¿h graÅ¿s, as Claver, &c. It Predominats over the more wild graÅ¿Å¿e, very little barren, much dry up-land and good meadow, Å¿ome phenny, Å¿wampy land, and Å¿mall running brooks and rivers throughout all the parts of the Countrey I have been, and theÅ¿e phenny and Å¿wampy Land hears great burdens of graÅ¿s; in Å¿hort, the land is four times better then I expected, we muÅ¿t needs be out Å¿ome money at preÅ¿ent to purchaÅ¿e lands of the Indians, but that will be Å¿oon got in with profit, as people come to Inhabite and take up Land, and pay as alwayes they have done their part of purchaÅ¿e from the Indians; Here is great talk of the braveries of the place and land, Barnagate I intend to Å¿ee Å¿hortly, after the Å¿eaÅ¿on is fititng, to go by land and water to it, I intend to go by water in a Sloop, to Å¿ee how convenient its by water, and from thence come by Land, Å¿o then I Å¿hall tell you more; Ye muÅ¿t expect to be at charges for doing theÅ¿e and Å¿uch other
things I purpoÅ¿e Å¿hortly to writ to, and demand in all places of the Quitrents, and Arriers, they generally Å¿ay, they will pay Captain Berry his two or three hundreth pounds behinds in arriers, as is Å¿aid becauÅ¿e his caice differs from others a little, I'le (GOD permitting) begin with them firÅ¿t of all about his rent, &c. and either have rent or land, what you write concerning building and repairing Å¿hall be ohÅ¿erved, I wiÅ¿h I were freely rid of all the goods I have of yours, and my own at 28. per cent. Excepting Å¿uch as are for the Indian Trade, TheÅ¿e part of America, are commodated with EngliÅ¿h goods; NevertheleÅ¿s when I pay Workmen and Labourers, I pay them goods rated cent per cent; New-York money, but then I muÅ¿t pay them 2. or 3. Å¿ilver, and part paction, which I procure with goods as well as I can.

The houÅ¿es at Amboy are 30. foot long and 16. foot wide, 10. foot betwixt joynt and joynt, a double Chimney made with Timber, and clay as the manner of this Countrey is to build, will in about 50. lib. a houÅ¿e, this pay procured here, for 25. in goods the firÅ¿t coaÅ¿t, I Å¿hall make you no return this year, Å¿eing we are about purchaÅ¿ing and Å¿urveying all, which will run
out money in this place, where Mint are Å¿o Å¿carce to be had on Å¿uch accounts, I muÅ¿t as well as I can turn your goods into money, proviÅ¿ion and goods for Indians, I have laid out Amboy into 150. Lots, and have Å¿ent home a draught of it,

div.head: AbÅ¿tract of a Letter from Gavin Laurie Deputy Governour of EaÅ¿t JerÅ¿ey, to the Proprietors at London, dated from Elizabeth Town the 2. of March, 1684.
div.p:
I Took up Å¿everal dayes with Countrey men and others, to view the Ground and Water, at laÅ¿t I pitched upon a place where a Ship of 300. Tun may ride Å¿afely within a plank length of the Shoar at low water, and joyning thereto is a peece of mariÅ¿h ground, about 12. pearch broad, and 20. pearch long, and high land on each Å¿ide like our Keyes by London Bridge; this may be eaÅ¿ie cut quit round for Å¿mal VeÅ¿Å¿els to come to the Key, and lye Å¿afe round this IÅ¿land, I Å¿et out Lots, 1. Acre a peece,
viz. 4. pole at the Key, and 40. pole backward, from thence along the river, near half a mile I lay'd out the like lotts very pleaÅ¿ant for Å¿cituation where they can Å¿ee the Å¿hips coming in the Bayes of Sandy-Hook; for near 20 miles the Ships may ride alongs by the Town as Å¿afe as at London, juÅ¿t at the point by the Town; Rariton-River runs up the Countrey a great way, there boats of 40 tun may goe, and the River, by the Town goes to New-York, HudÅ¿ons-River Long IÅ¿land, Staten IÅ¿land, and Å¿o to New-England; there is no place in all England for Conveniency and pleaÅ¿ant Å¿cituation; There are 60 Lotts upon the River, and 40 backward between theÅ¿e and the River, and theÅ¿e backward have a highway 100 foot broad, where I have laid out a place for a mercat, with croÅ¿s Streets from the River to the Market where the Town-houÅ¿es are to be built; when this was done I laid out 400 Acres to be divided in 48 parts, viz. 36 to each Proprietor, and thoÅ¿e who have Lotts in the Town, I grant them half Lotts in this to pay for the Lotts in the Town, 20 pound or if a half Lott of 36 Acres
40 pounds; I laid 400 Acres to ly untill the Proprietors agree to devyd it as people comes over; There is 16 Lotts taken up by the ScotiÅ¿h Proprietors, and 8 Lotts by the Proprietors that are here; There are 20 Lotts taken up in the Town by other People; I engadge all to build a houÅ¿e of 30 foot long, and 18 broad, and 18 foot high to the raiÅ¿ing, to be finiÅ¿hed within a year, To pay for laying out 40 Å¿hil: a Lot, and 4 d per Annum, Quit-Rent there are Å¿everal begun already to build, I have laid out between 40 and 50 Acres for the Governours houÅ¿e. The high way and wharfe between the Hooks and the River a 100 foot broad; And to â¢ eave a raw of trees along upon the River before the houÅ¿es for Å¿hade & Å¿halter exceeding pleaÅ¿ant: I have agreed for two houÅ¿es of like demenÅ¿ions, to be built for the Proprietors; and alÅ¿o a houÅ¿e for the Governour of 6 foot long, & 18 foot broad And if the quit rents come in, I intend 3 or 4 houÅ¿es more for the Proprietors, I can eaÅ¿ily let them this work took me up 5 weeks After I had finiÅ¿hed this work I Å¿et the people to work, ScotiÅ¿h and EngliÅ¿h, about 50 perÅ¿ons, Å¿ome preparing, for building, other on
clearing ground to get Corn Å¿owne, this Å¿pring, then came in a Boar privatly to Elizabeth Town the 12th. paÅ¿t next morning; I went to New-York to viÅ¿it the Governour, Å¿tayed there two or three days; He was very kind and promiÅ¿ed a fair correÅ¿pondency, Å¿o I did not publiÅ¿h my CommiÅ¿Å¿ion untill this day before the Council; They have been kind and courteous: Now is the time to Å¿end over people for Å¿ettling theÅ¿e. There is 30000 Acres of Land in Å¿everal places belonging to Proprietors formerly taken up by Cartwright, Å¿o here is land enough. The Scots and William Dorkwrans people coming now and Å¿ettling, advance the Province more then it hath been advanced theÅ¿e ten years. Therefore Proprietors Å¿end over Å¿ome Families and Servants; I Å¿hall preÅ¿ently Å¿et them out Land, and it well preÅ¿ently bring them in conÅ¿iderable profite in a few years here wants; nothing but people; There is not a poor body in all the Province, nor that wants; Here is abundance of ProviÅ¿ion, Pork and Beef. At 2 d per pound, FiÅ¿h and Fowl plenty; OyÅ¿ters I think would Å¿erve all England, Wheat 4. Å¿hil. Ster. per.
BuÅ¿hell, Indian Wheat 2. Å¿s. 6. d. per buÅ¿Å¿hell; It is exceeding good food every way, and 2. or 300. fold increaÅ¿s; Sider good and plenty for 1. d. per Quart; Good drink that is made of water and MolaÅ¿Å¿es Å¿tands in about 2. Å¿s. per. Barrel wholeÅ¿ome like our 8. Å¿s: Beer in England, Good VeniÅ¿ion plenty brought, us in at 18. d. the quarter, Eggs at 3. d. per Dozon; all things very plenty, Land very good as ever I Å¿ee; Wines, Walnuts, Peaches, Straw-berries and many other things plenty in the woods; The Proprietors have 150. or 200. Acres 3. miles from the town upon Rariton River, Å¿alt MarÅ¿h where I intend to let the people of Amboy cut graÅ¿s for hay to their Cattle in Winter, untill we otherwayes order it, by Lots to them; I reckon there is laid out for the Town Governours houÅ¿e, and publick high wayes, near or about 200. Acres, Å¿o there reÅ¿ts 1800. Acres, I laid 400. Acres as I Å¿aid the reÅ¿t to ly in common untill divided; I have put two houÅ¿es in repair upon the River called the Point, 2. m: from Elizabeth Town, have let one of them with 10. Acres of PaÅ¿ture ground, and 10. Acres of Woody ground for 7. years at 26: lib. per annum; the
man to clear the ten Acres of Woody ground, and make it fit for Pleuching or PaÅ¿ture; I intend to let the other alÅ¿o with Å¿ome land, all the houÅ¿es were like to drop down, all the land lying wothout fence, and an barn quit falen down, and deÅ¿troyed, another without any cover; And that other next to the houÅ¿e where I dwell all to peices, and all the fences and out-houÅ¿es is down, but repairsd before I came; I am Å¿etting up a Ferry-Boat at Perth, for Men and HorÅ¿es to go and come to Burlingtown, PenÅ¿alvania, and New-York; AlÅ¿o I am treating with one to Å¿et up a houÅ¿e midway to Burlingtown, to entertain Travellors, and a Ferry-Boat to go to New-York, all which is for promotting Perth, that being the center; alÅ¿o you Å¿hould give me power to Å¿et out a Line between the Governour of New-York and us; he calls on me for it, becauÅ¿e Å¿everal Plantations on the River are Å¿ettled, and we know not yet what Å¿ide they will fall to; I cannot at preÅ¿ent mention all particulars, which you muÅ¿t Å¿upply by Å¿ome general clauÅ¿es or words, for it is not poÅ¿Å¿ible for you to underÅ¿tand what is for the good of the Province as I do, that am here; and be not Å¿paring to Å¿end over people, it will bring you it again with large profits; for here is a gallant plentifull
Countrey, and good land; I bave given you a large account of the little time I have been here; I have none to writ for me; but you muÅ¿t Å¿end a Coppy of this to Scotland, and with it your further InÅ¿tructions to be Å¿igned, and Å¿end me forth; I will be bound till it come, I reÅ¿t your friend, Sic Å¿ubÅ¿cribitur,

div.head: An Letter from Gavin Laury to a Friend of his at London.
div.p:
I PromiÅ¿ed to write to thee when GOD brought me to JerÅ¿ey, but had not time till now, I Å¿hall give thee a breef, account of the Countrey, no fiction but the truth; It is beyond what I expected, It is Å¿cituate in a good Aire, which makes it healthy; and there is great conveniency for travelling from places throw the Province in Boats, from a Å¿mall Canoa to VeÅ¿sels of 30, 40, or 50, Tun, and in Å¿ome places 100; In the Bay coming up to Amboy point, where the Town of Perth is now in building, a Ship of 300. Tun may aÅ¿ily ride cloÅ¿s to the Shoar, within a plank
length to the Shoar, and the houÅ¿es of the Town, and yet the land there, nor other in the Province is not low, Swampy MariÅ¿h ground but pretty high ground, riÅ¿ing from the water Å¿ide at Amboy point, the bank of the River is 20. foot, in Å¿ome places 30, and in Å¿ome 40. foot high; And yet hath many conveniencies for landing goods, The Å¿oile is generally black in Å¿ome places a foot deep, beareth great burthens of Corn, and Naturally bringeth forth EngliÅ¿h graÅ¿s 2. years pleuching, the ground is tender and the ploughing is very eaÅ¿ie, the trees grow generally not thick, but Å¿ome places 10, in Å¿ome 15, in Å¿ome 25, or 30. upon an Acre; This I find generally, but in Å¿ome particular places there is 100. upon an Acre, but that is very rare; The trees are very tale and Å¿traight, the generall are Oak, Beech, Walnut, ChaÅ¿nuts, and Accorns ly thick upon the ground for want of eating, Peaches, Vines, Strawberries â¢ nd many other Å¿orts of Fruits grow commonly in the Woods; There is likewayes Gumtree, Cedar, White-Wood, like our Fir-tree, Walnuts, CheÅ¿nuts, and others lye tick upon the ground; there is great plenty of OyÅ¿ters, FiÅ¿h, Foul, Pork is 2. pennies the pound, Beef, and VeniÅ¿on 1. penny the pound; a whole fat back at 5. or 6.
per BuÅ¿hell, Indian Corn for 26 per BuÅ¿hel, Oats, 20. pennies, and Barley 2. Å¿hill: per BuÅ¿hell; We have good brick earth, and Å¿tone for building, at Amboy and elÅ¿ewhere the Countrey Farme houÅ¿es are built very cheap, A Carpentar with a mans own Servants builds the houÅ¿e, they have all materialls for nothing, except Nails; their Chimneys are of Å¿tones, they make their own Ploughs and Carts for the moÅ¿t part, only the Iron work is very dear; The poorer Å¿ort Å¿et up a houÅ¿e of two or three Rooms themÅ¿elves after this manner, The walls are of cloven Timber about 8. or 10. Inches broad, like planks Å¿et on end to the ground; and the other nailed to the raiÅ¿ing which they plaiÅ¿ter within; they build a Barn after the Å¿ame manner, and theÅ¿e coÅ¿t not above 5. lib. a peece, and then to w â¢ rk they go. 2. or 3. men in one year will clear 50. Acres, in Å¿ome places 60. and in Å¿ome more; They Å¿ow Corn the firÅ¿t year, and afterwards maintain themÅ¿elves, and the encreaÅ¿e of Corn, Cows, HorÅ¿es, Hogs and Sheep, comes to the Landlord; Å¿everal Merchants of New-York, have left their Å¿everal Plantations there to come to EaÅ¿t-Jer-Å¿ey; 2. or 3. joyn together be 12, 15, or 20. Servants and one OverÅ¿eer, which coÅ¿ts them nothing for the firÅ¿t year, except Å¿ome Shoes,
Stockings and Shirts; I have been to Å¿ee theÅ¿e Plantations, and find they make a great increaÅ¿e by them, maintains their Families at New-York with all proviÅ¿ions; Å¿ell a great deal yearly, and for Servants our EngliÅ¿h people are far better Husbandmen then the New-England men, the Servants work not Å¿o much by a third as they do in England, and I think feed much better, for they have Beef, Pork, Baccon, Pudding, Milk, Butter, and good Beer; and Cyder for drink: When they are out of their time, they have land for themÅ¿elves; and generally turn Farmours for themÅ¿elves; Servants wages is not under 2: Å¿hill: a day beÅ¿ides Victuals; and at Amboy point 2: Å¿hill: 6: pen: per day, at Amboy we have one Å¿etting up to make Malt, but we want a Brewar, I wiÅ¿h thou would Å¿end over Å¿ome to Å¿et up a BrewhouÅ¿e and a BakehouÅ¿e to bake Bread and Bisket, for a Bisket-maker we muÅ¿t have to vend our meat to the Plantations, Å¿end over Å¿ome Husband Men and Countrey Fellows that Plough, Sow, Reap, ThreÅ¿h and look after Cattle; A Carpentar or two, and a Smith for Ploughs and HorÅ¿e, and a Cowper, which we want very much; If thou will Å¿end a dozon of Servants, moÅ¿t of them Countrey men, I will Å¿et thee out a gallant Plantation of
500. or 1000. Acres upon a River Å¿ide; but thou muÅ¿t Å¿end over Å¿ome goods to Å¿tock it withall, I deÅ¿ire thee to encourage Å¿ome of our Friends, eÅ¿pecially the Proprietors to Å¿end over Å¿ome Å¿ervants to Å¿tock Å¿ome Land, And when they have cleared it, if they have a mind to lett it, here are tennents to take it, and if they will Å¿ell it, here are alÅ¿o purchaÅ¿ers; there is one man Å¿ince I came here Å¿old his Plantation for 1500. lib. the whole was 1600. or 1800. Acres, whereof only 120. Acres were cleared, upon which he had a houÅ¿e, Garden and Orchyard, and Barn planted; I know Å¿everal men who lett cleared Land at 6. Å¿hil 8. pennies and at 10. Å¿hil. the Acre yearlie rent, which is a good encouragement for Å¿ending over Å¿ervants to plant; I write not this as idle Å¿tory, but as things realy and truly are; I have Å¿ent for Å¿ervants my Å¿elf to Å¿etle a farme for if the Proprietors will not do Å¿o, I Å¿ee not what they can exect. The Scots have taken a right courÅ¿e, They have Å¿ent over many Å¿ervants, and are likewayes Å¿ending more; They have likewayes Å¿ent over many poor Families, and given them a Å¿mall Å¿tock, and theÅ¿e Families Å¿ome for 7. Å¿ome for 10 years give the half of their increaÅ¿e to the Land-lord, except the milk, which the tennent hath to himÅ¿elf, I have Å¿et
them out land, and they are at work, I beleive they will have 40. Acres cleared this Spring; and this Summer I am to Å¿ett them out more, Å¿o that in a Å¿hort time they will have a great increaÅ¿s coming in, this will raiÅ¿e the price of the Land here; And is the reaÅ¿on that Å¿everal from New-York bounds come to me, to take up Land, for they beleive now this Province will be improven; And our Land is beeter then theirs; Å¿o that every Proprietors Å¿ending over 10. people will be a great advantage to himÅ¿elf, encourage others to take up Land and bring all the diviÅ¿ion that hath been here to an end, for theÅ¿e men Å¿eing that they Å¿hall be ballanced are already more complyant then they were, Now I have layd theÅ¿e things before thee, and deÅ¿ire thee to impart them to Å¿ome of the Proprietors, and other friends that they may conÅ¿ider of the Å¿ame, I am thy Loving friend; Sic Å¿ubÅ¿cribtur,

div.head: A Letter from Gavin Laury to the Scots Proprietors of the Å¿ame date.
div.p:
KNowing you do expect from us an account of this Countrey, we have for your encouragement, and for the encouragement of all
our Countrey Men who may be inclinable to come into this Countrey, given you this breef and true account of it, according as we have Å¿een and are credibly informed, for having Å¿een little, yet Å¿ave the Winter SeaÅ¿on, we muÅ¿t writ what is to be Å¿een in Summer, upon Information which we have juÅ¿t ground to believe to be true, becauÅ¿e what we have Å¿een alread in it (notwithÅ¿tanding of all that we heard of it before we came) Å¿urpaÅ¿s our expectation in many things; the Aire in this Countrey is very wholeÅ¿ome, and though it alter Å¿uddenly Å¿ometimes being one day hot and another cold, yet people are not Å¿o Å¿ubject to catch cold, or be diÅ¿tempered by it as in our Countrey of England; the land lyes for the moÅ¿t part pretty high, but on the River and Creek Å¿ides are many Meadows which lye low, of which the Countrey people getts their Hay, whereby their Å¿tocks are maintained in the Winter SeaÅ¿on, ProviÅ¿ions here are pentifull and cheap; There is Beef, Pork, VeniÅ¿ion, Mutton, Foul and FiÅ¿h, aboundance to be had at eaÅ¿ie rates, and for drink they have good Beer, and Cyder, and theÅ¿e that are deÅ¿irous
may have Wine of Å¿everal Å¿orts, and other kinds of Å¿trong Liquor, Å¿o that we Å¿ee little wanting here that a man can deÅ¿ire; and we are here Å¿ure that a Å¿ober and induÅ¿trious People might make this a rich Countrey, and enrich themÅ¿elves in it, eÅ¿pecially poor people who are hard put to it to gain bread at home; notwithÅ¿tanding of the exceÅ¿Å¿ive Labour, for we Å¿ee that people here want nothing, & yet there labour is very Å¿aml; they work not Å¿o hard by one half as the Husband men or Fermors in our Countrey; and many of theÅ¿e who have Å¿etled here upwards of Å¿ixteen years, have lived upon the product of the Land; They cleared the firÅ¿t two years after they came (and cleared none Å¿ince) which produced not only Corn to maintain their own Families, but to Å¿ell every year, and the encreaÅ¿e of their BeÅ¿tial whereof they have good Å¿tore of Å¿everal Sorts, Cows, Oxen, HorÅ¿es, Sheep, and Swine, yeelds them other proviÅ¿ions and to Å¿ell; beÅ¿ides, yet there be Å¿ome more InduÅ¿trious among them who have continued clearing and Improving Land, and theÅ¿e have got EÅ¿tates, and would not
Å¿ell their Plantations for Å¿everal hundred pounds, we have late up a little way on the Rariton River, but could not go Å¿o far as we intended being prevented by Rainy weather, but Å¿o far as we went was very rich land, and yet that above it is Å¿aid to be richer, a great deal of it is naturally clear of wood; And which is not Å¿o, is eaÅ¿ily cleared, the trees being but Å¿mall and a good diÅ¿tance from one another, Å¿o that the Land yet untaken up Å¿o far as we can underÅ¿tand, is eaÅ¿ier to clear then that which is taken up; the Towns that are already Å¿eated, being Å¿eated in woodieÅ¿t places, the Merchants in New-York both Dutch and EngliÅ¿h have many of them taken up Land and Å¿etled Plantations in this Countrey, and Å¿everall from that Collony are deÅ¿iring to come and take up land among us, though they might have land in their own Collony without paying Quittrents; The wood here is not Å¿o hard to clear as many think, they do not pull it up by the Roots, but them about a foot or more from the ground; and one man may cut down many in a day, four of our men the firÅ¿t day they began, cut down Å¿eventy
the beÅ¿t Trees they could find fit for building; there are not many of great Trees, but Å¿traight and tale, and there be of many Å¿orts, Oak, Walnut, CheÅ¿nut, Cedar, Popler, Gumtrees, Firrs, Pines, Birth and Beech, and other Å¿orts which we remember not at preÅ¿ent; there are many good Orchards of Fruit trees, and they make abundance of good Cyder, eÅ¿pecially at one Town called New-wark, which is eÅ¿teemed at New-York and other places where it is Å¿old, beyond any that comes from New-England; there are Peaches, and Vines grow wild about the River Å¿ides, which in SeaÅ¿on bears good Fruit, and Grapes, and there are Strawberries over all the Woods and many other kind of goods and Fruits, and at Amboy point and Å¿everal other places there is abundance of brave OyÅ¿ters: There will be many houÅ¿es built there quickly, for many have taken up lots and all that have taken are oblieged to built within a year; there is good encouragment for TradÅ¿men to come over, Å¿uch as Carpentars, MaÅ¿Å¿ons and Brick-layers, for they build not only of Wood, but alÅ¿o of Stone and Brick, yet moÅ¿t
of Countrey HouÅ¿es are built of Wood, only Trees Å¿plit and Å¿e â¢ up in end on the Ground, and Coverings to their HouÅ¿es are moÅ¿tly Shingles made of Oak, CheÅ¿nut and Cedar wood, which makes a very neat Covering, yet there are Å¿ome HouÅ¿es covered after the Dutch manner with pantikles; the Towns are all Å¿ettled upon Rivers, where VeÅ¿Å¿els of 30, or 40, Tuns may come up to their doors, and the out plantations generally upon Å¿ome Brooks or Rivelets which are as plenty here as in our own Countrey, and curious clear water, and in many places are good Spring walls; but in the Towns every man for the moÅ¿t part have a well diggd by his own hand: Among all the towns that are Setled here, there is none lyeth Å¿o convenient for trade as New-Perth, for Shipps of great burden may come up cloÅ¿s to the houÅ¿es, and may come up any time in the Winter; There came a Ship of 300. tuns in there this winter, in the hardeÅ¿t froÅ¿t we had, and lay hard by the town, Å¿o near that Å¿he was tyed to a tree: The Land here; brings furth moÅ¿t Å¿orts of EngliÅ¿h grain, and great encreaÅ¿e, Wheat, Rye, Barly,
Oats and others Å¿orts of grain, Å¿uch as Indian Corn, which is very good and wholeÅ¿ome kind of Grain; and alÅ¿o Buck-Wheat, and thoÅ¿e Corns are to be had at eaÅ¿ie rates, either for money or for goods, and thoÅ¿e that have not m â¢â¦
ney or goods may have abundance for their work.
We Å¿hall now anÅ¿wer Å¿o far as we are capable, your Quarries Å¿ent over to us.

To the firÅ¿t, we cannot poÅ¿itively anÅ¿wer to give an account of the whole length and breadth of the Province, But we are informed that it is a great deale broader then ye expected, for theÅ¿e that have travelled from the extent of our bounds on HudÅ¿ons-River Å¿traight over to the Delawar-River, Å¿ay it is 100. myles or upwards; we Å¿hall know that certainly after a while, for the Line betwixt us and New-York is to be run Å¿traight over to Delaware-River, about 3. weeks hence, and after that the Line betwixt us and WeÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, After which we Å¿hall be able to give a true account of the bounds of that Province.

2ly. When the bounds is Å¿o exactly laid out we can the eaÅ¿ier gueÅ¿s at the Number of Acres, and by that time may be able to give an account what number of Acres is already taken up, but there is no fear of want of Land.

3ly. The quantity of Meadow ground we cannot determine, having travelled as yet but litle in the Province, but the way we have travelled, there is meadow abundance, both on the water Å¿ides and on the up Land.

4ly. There is alÅ¿o other good ground in Å¿ome places great quantities free of wood, which is fit either for Corn or GraÅ¿s, and the ground all over brings furth good EngliÅ¿h graÅ¿s naturaly after it is ploughed.

5ly. There are alÅ¿o Commons upon the Countrey, but what quantity we cannot tell, there is litle keept in them Å¿ave wild horÅ¿es, which the people take up when they have occaÅ¿ion; There is alÅ¿o Land fit for paÅ¿turage for Sheep, and there is their Sheep in the Countrey; but what number the ableÅ¿t planters have we know not, but Å¿ome we Å¿ee have good flocks.
6ly. An exact Mapp of the Countrey is not yet drawn nor can you quickly expect it, for it will tak up a great deale of time, charge and pains to doe it.
7ly. There are alÅ¿o hills up in the Countrey, but how much ground they take up we know not, they are Å¿aid to be Å¿tony and covered with wood, and beyond them is Å¿aid to be excellent land.
8ly. To the Eight we cannot anÅ¿wer as yet.

9ly, There be People of Å¿everal Å¿orts of Religion, but few very Zealous; The People being moÅ¿tly New-England men, doe moÅ¿tly incline to their way, and in every Town there is a meeting houÅ¿e where they worÅ¿hip publickly every Week; They have no publick Law in the Countrey for mantaining publick Teachers; but the Towns that have them makes way within themÅ¿elves to maintain them; We know none that hath a Å¿etled Preacher that followes no other Imployment, Å¿ave one Town New-wark.
10ly. The method of building their houÅ¿es is mentioned already.

11ly. There are not many Out Plantations that are not within the bounds of Å¿ome Town; Yet there be Å¿ome, and theÅ¿e are the richeÅ¿t, what number are there we know not, Å¿ome have great quantities of Land and abundance cleared.

12ly. The richeÅ¿t Planters have not above 8. or 10. Servants, they will have Å¿ome of them 1 Dozon of Cowes, yea Å¿ome 20. or 30. 8. or 10. Oxen, horÅ¿e more then they know themÅ¿elves, for they keep breading Mears, and keep no more horÅ¿es at home then they have occaÅ¿ion to work; The reÅ¿t they let run in the woo â¢ both Winter and Summer, and take them as they have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e them; Swine they have in great flocks in the wood, and Sheep in flocks alÅ¿o, but they lett them not run in the woods for fear of being deÅ¿troyed by wolves; Their profite ariÅ¿es from the Improvement of their Land, and IncreaÅ¿e of their BeÅ¿tial.

13ly. There will be in moÅ¿t of the Towns already Å¿ettled at leaÅ¿t 100 HouÅ¿es, but they are not built Å¿o regular as the Towns in our Countrey, Å¿o that we cannot compear them with any Town we know in Scotland; every houÅ¿e in the Town hath a Lott of 4. Acres lying to it; Å¿o that every one building upon his
own Lott makes the town Irregular and Å¿cattered; There Å¿treets are laid out too large, and the Sheep in the Towns are moÅ¿tly mantained in them; They are Å¿o large that they need not trouble to pave them.

14ly. Betwixt Sandy-Hook, and Little Egg harbor lyes 2. Towns Midletoun and Shrewsbery, there is no Land taken up that way but what is in the bounds of theÅ¿e two Towns; what kind of land it is, we know not, having never travelled that way, Bornogate or Burning-Holl is Å¿aid to be a very good place for fiÅ¿hing, and there is Å¿ome deÅ¿iring to take up land there, who inform us that it is good Land, and abundance of Meadow lying to it.

15ly. There are no FiÅ¿her-men that follows only that trade, Å¿ave Å¿ome that Å¿alt Whales upon the Coa â¢ ts, and other FiÅ¿hes, there is abundance to be had every where through the Countrey in all the Rivers, and the People commonly fiÅ¿h with Å¿ives or long netts, and will catch with a Å¿ive 1. Å¿ometimes 2. barrels a day, of good fiÅ¿h, which they Å¿alt up moÅ¿tly for their own uÅ¿e, and to Å¿ell to others.

16ly. There is no Ships belonging to this Province particularly, or built here, Å¿ave one which Samuel Groome built here the laÅ¿t Summer, which Å¿tands yet in the Stocks (a Å¿top being put to it by his death;) there is conveniency enough to build Shippes, the Shippes in this part trade moÅ¿tly to the WeÅ¿t-Indian IÅ¿lands, and Å¿ome to New found-Land, where the ProviÅ¿ions of this Countrey vends.

17ly. There is land here in Å¿everal places, after it is cleared and brought into a farm Å¿ett out for Rent â¢ , as in out Countrey at 5.8. and 10. Å¿hil. per Acre. According to the goodneÅ¿s and Å¿cituation of the Å¿aid Land, and thoÅ¿e that will be at charge to clear land may get tennents to take upon theÅ¿e termes; But whither it will turn to good account or not becauÅ¿e little experienced as yet with the Charge of clearing of Land. I will not poÅ¿itivly inform.
18ly. There is Å¿everal places of rhe Countrey fit for mills, and Å¿everal both Corn and Saw mills already Å¿ett up, and good encouragment to Å¿ett up more.

19ly. The Acres are here reckoned according
to the EngliÅ¿h Account; There is 16 foot goes to the Rude, and 20. Rude long and 8. Rude broad, makes an Acre; One EngliÅ¿h butt of Wheat which is 8 EngliÅ¿h Gallons or Scots Quarts, commonly Å¿ows an Acres 2. buÅ¿hells of Barlay alÅ¿o an Acre, and 2. buÅ¿hells of Oats an Acre, and half Acre; EngliÅ¿h peck which is 4. EngliÅ¿h quarts or Scots Shopens, of Indian Corn plants one Acre.

20. There are but few Indian-Natives, in this Countrey; Their Å¿trength is inconÅ¿iderable, they live in the Woods, and have Å¿mall towns in Å¿ome places far up in the Countrey; They plant a little Indian Corn, Å¿hoots Deer, and other wild BeaÅ¿ts and Fowls for their food; They have Kings among themÅ¿elves to Govern them; for Religion, they have none at all, they do not refuÅ¿e to Å¿ell Land at occaÅ¿ion.

p.hi: The prices of Grain and other ProviÅ¿ions here at preÅ¿ent,

div.p:
Indian Corn, 2. Å¿s. 6. d. the BuÅ¿hell, Wheat 4 Å¿hill: Rye, 3. Å¿hill: Oats, 1. Å¿s. 8. d. the BuÅ¿hel, Beef, 1 d. Pork 2. d. VeniÅ¿on 1 d. Mutton 3 d. the pound, this EngliÅ¿h MeaÅ¿ure and Weight; But mark
theÅ¿e things being valued in this Countrey money, there is a fifth part difference betwixt it and Sterling money, So that Wheat being valued here at 4. Å¿s. the BuÅ¿hel, is but 3 Å¿s. 3. d. Sterling, and Å¿o of the reÅ¿t proportionally.

p.hi: Here you have an Account of things as far as we are capable to give you at preÅ¿ent, with which we hope you will be Å¿atisfied, while further opportunity and better experience give us occaÅ¿ion to writ more; And Å¿o we reÅ¿t your Friends and will wiÅ¿hers to all our Country Men.

closer.signed:
Sic Å¿ubÅ¿cribitur,
David Barclay.
