div.head: A Letter, from George Mackenzie Merchant in Edinburgh, to Mr. George Alexander Advocat there.
div.p:
I Doubt not but you expect here a particular account of the province of New-JerÅ¿ey, but that I thought needleÅ¿s, The perÅ¿on David Barclay whom this comes alongÅ¿t with, being more able to give you that Å¿atisfaction, as whoÅ¿e intereÅ¿t oblidgeth him to a more narrow obÅ¿ervation of its natural advantages, and whoÅ¿e place being one of the Council, gives a larger liberty and occaÅ¿ion to inÅ¿pect the concerns of this Province; But in general its a healthfull, pleaÅ¿ant fruitful Country, in many places of a moÅ¿t Luxurious Soyle, rewarding the labour of the Countryman Å¿ufficiently, its well watered with many fair and pleaÅ¿ant Rivers and Creeks, Å¿tored with Å¿everal Å¿orts of fiÅ¿h, and moÅ¿t of the Rivulets convenient for mills, whereof there are Å¿everall both for Å¿owing of wood and grinding of Corn. They raiÅ¿e great Å¿tore of Hogs & Cattle; and fowls they have in abundance; The Countrey for ten or fifteen miles up from the River and Sea is generally plain; farther up Mountains, beÅ¿ides the Towns mentioned in the publick paper Å¿ince Governor Lawries arrivall, there is laid out at Amboy-point 1000. Acres for the City of Perth divided into 96. Lotts, 9 Acres to a Lott, the Remainders is for the Å¿treets, Mercat place, Governours houÅ¿e, and other publick conveniencies. How large the Countrey is, is a queÅ¿tion hard to reÅ¿olve,
and how much bought by the Proprietors (if any) David Bar â¢ lay can Å¿atisfy you, The inhabitants are EngliÅ¿h, with a few Scots, French, and Dutch of Å¿ufficient number, to defend themÅ¿ â¢ lves againÅ¿t any prejudice may be offered them by the Inhabitants. That fancie of a Common Improvement will not take, but whoever expects profi â¢ e from their IntereÅ¿ts here, muÅ¿t Imp â¢ ove them a part, I have Å¿old Å¿ome of your Gloves a â¢ 2 Å¿hil: and 6 pen: 3 Å¿hil: 4: pen. a pair, being what I c â¢ uld gett for â¢ hem; the money five and a half part leÅ¿s then IngliÅ¿h, and Å¿hal make an account thereof at meeting, PreÅ¿ â¢ nt my Å¿ervice to all Friends.

closer.signed: I am Your very humble Servant, Sic Å¿cribitur, George Mackenzie

div.head: A Double of a Letter from New-Perth, da â¢ ed the 1 of the Å¿eventh Moneth, 1684. From Iohn Reid, who was Gardner to the Lord Advocat, to a Friend at Edinburgh.
div.p:
SEing it hath pl â¢ Å¿ead God to bring me and mine Å¿afe unto this part, I took upon my Å¿elf as oblidged to writ Å¿omething according to my promiÅ¿e of this Countrey; indeed I muÅ¿t Å¿a â¢ its a brave place, but I have nor had time to take Å¿uch obÅ¿ervations as I w â¢ uld, being Å¿o ingadged to attend my other buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e; Here is no ou â¢ ward want, eÅ¿pecially of proviÅ¿ions, and if people were induÅ¿truos they might have cloaths alÅ¿o within themÅ¿elves; by the report â¢ f all, its the beÅ¿t of all â¢ he Neighbouring Collonies, it is very wholeÅ¿ome, pleaÅ¿ant, and a fertill-land,
there are alÅ¿o Å¿ome barren land, viz. whit Sandy land, full of Pin trees, it lyes betwixt South-River, and Barngate on NeverÅ¿Å¿ink, (albiet there be alÅ¿o much good land in that precinct) yet its a good place for raiÅ¿ing a Å¿tock of cattle, providing they have large room to run in, for cattle finds g â¢ od food there in winter, when none is in the beÅ¿t land, and therefore do the inhabitants provide little hay in winter. The Å¿oyl of the countrey is generally a red marle ear â¢ h, with a Å¿urface of blak mould (nor doth it appear that realy it is to their eyes; who cannot penetrat beyond the Å¿urface) full fraughted with graÅ¿s, pleaÅ¿ant hearbs, and flowers, and in many places little or no wood, but moÅ¿t places full of large timber, as walnut, eÅ¿pecially oak, there be Å¿ome places here and there in the Woods, they call Å¿wamps, whick is low Ground, amidÅ¿t or betwixt riÅ¿ing ground full of buÅ¿hes, which holds water in winter, tho moÅ¿t of them be dry in Å¿ummer, but theÅ¿e being cleared, and Å¿ome of them that needs being drained, are the richeÅ¿t land; here are great conveniencies of Bay, Sounds, Rivers, Creeks, Brooks, and Springs, all over the Province; but one of the beÅ¿t things is the large quantities of brave Meadowes, both falt and freÅ¿h, which makes the people here able to Å¿upply their Neighbours as they doe, throw the abundance of their cattle. I know one Planter who hath a hundred of cattle, not above three years Å¿etled, and no wonder for Å¿ome of the graÅ¿Å¿e is als high as my head; Its pity to Å¿ee Å¿o much good land as I have been over in this province lying waÅ¿t, and greater pity to Å¿ee Å¿o much good and convenient land taken, and not improven.

As Å¿oon as any of the land here comes to be cultivated, it over-runs with Å¿mall Claver-graÅ¿s, by the
paÅ¿turage and dunging of cattle, and Å¿o Å¿upplants the naturall graÅ¿s and hearbs, notwithÅ¿tanding of their quick and Å¿trong growth, Fruit trees alÅ¿o proÅ¿per well here; Newark made about a thouÅ¿and barrell of Å¿ider laÅ¿t year (a barrell is 8 Scots gallons) this is like that of Woodbridge; who made 500 barrels of pork in one year, before the law was made againÅ¿t the Å¿wins treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es.

Here they Å¿ow moÅ¿t Indian corn, and Wheat, Å¿ome Rye, Barly, Oats, Indian corn the firÅ¿t year that they break up or plough, the Å¿econd they Å¿ow Whea â¢ , becauÅ¿e the Å¿pontaneous grouth of the weeds is done away by howing the Indean corn, as we do cabboge; here is one planter makes accompt, That he hath about three thouÅ¿and buÅ¿hels of wheat reapt this year; I Å¿uppoÅ¿e he hath above a hundred acres of it, but I doe not make theÅ¿e inÅ¿tances as Å¿o many precedents.

I know nothing wanting here, except that good TradÅ¿men, and good Husbandmen, and Labourers are Å¿carce; a Labourer may have a buÅ¿hell of Corn per day, when he is a little acquainted with the work of the country, but TradÅ¿men much more, Smiths, Carpenters, MaÅ¿ons, Weavers, Taylors, Shoemakers, are very acceptable; any who comes let them bring Å¿ome cloaths, and their proper tools with them, as uÅ¿ed in England, and provide butter, bisket, wine, and eÅ¿pecially beer and ale, for their Sea-voyage, beÅ¿ides the Å¿hips allowance, and they need not fear when they come here, albiet they have no more, yet they will be the better if they have Å¿omething, either in money or Scots linning, and Å¿tuffs to buy a little proviÅ¿ion at firÅ¿t, to Å¿et them up a houÅ¿e, and buy a cow or two; and tho a man be rich, I would not adviÅ¿e him ro bring many Å¿ervants, at leaÅ¿t not to keep many at firÅ¿t, untill he Å¿ee about him, and know what he is doing.

I Cannot tell what goods are beÅ¿t to bring, David Barclay can tell better; But he who brings money, may expect 15. d. For the EngliÅ¿h; Å¿hil: Å¿ome may bring a Little of the beÅ¿t Wheat for a change of Å¿eed, and Å¿ome barly, and Oats, for the Å¿ame uÅ¿e; alÅ¿o a Litle Scots field piÅ¿e, there being none Å¿uch here, bring alÅ¿o Å¿ome great clower Å¿eed.

There are great Å¿tore of Garding hearbs here, I have not had time to inquire unto them all, nether to Å¿end Å¿ome of the many pleaÅ¿ant (tho to me unknown plants of this Countrey, to James Sutherland PhyÅ¿ick Gardiner at Edinburgh, but tell him, I will not forget him, when opportunities offers.

I had forgot to writ of Ambo, or New-Perth, therefore I add, that it is one of the beÅ¿t places in America, by the report of all Travellers, for a town of trade; for my part, I never Å¿aw any Å¿o conveniently Å¿eated; this with my love, and my Wifs to all friends, and acquaintances,

closer.signed: I ReÅ¿t thy friend, John Reid.

div.head: David Mudies Letter to his Wife.
div.p:
I Hope this Å¿hall find you and your Children in Good-health, and I wiÅ¿h in as much Å¿atisfaction as I and our Children are here, far beyond my expectation, and others my well-wiÅ¿hers, who are
with you, my laÅ¿t to you was upon my arrival here, dated the 8th of November, and at that time I could give you but a Å¿mall account of my Judgement anent it, it would take a great deale of time to inform you of every thing, as it truelie is; But to be Å¿hort, I have travelled through a part of it, and it is far larger than ever I heard it reported in Scotland: I dare Å¿ay, above a third more ground, and there is abundance of brave Rivers through â¢ t all, â¢ better then ever I did Å¿ee in any place, brave Meadows al â¢â¢â¢ Å¿t all the River Å¿ides: and lands above the Mead â¢ w ground, abundance of FreÅ¿h water Brooks, and Springs, plenty of FiÅ¿hes in all the Rivers, in the Summer time, and that very good FiÅ¿hes Å¿uch as they preÅ¿erve for Victual in the W â¢ nter, and in very few days they uÅ¿e to take more then they make uÅ¿ â¢ of in Winter; as for wild Meat there is of all Å¿orts; Cows, Å¿heep and Oxen as large as in England, and aboundantly cheap, conÅ¿idering their goodneÅ¿s, Corns and all Sorts of Fruit in great aboundance, and no leÅ¿s then they are called in Scotland. Mo â¢â¢ y within this three years is become pretty plentiful, Servants dear and Å¿carce, I have taken up Å¿ex Acres of Land in New-Perth, which pleaÅ¿es me exceeding well, in regard it is good Land, and f â¢â¢
â¢â¢ r building of a City, and PerÅ¿ons of Good Fortune a â¢ e come from New-York, and other places in th â¢ Countrey, and are very buÅ¿y building; and I a â¢â¢ begun to build a houÅ¿e, and have near digged the ground, which is very hard, it being under a great part of it Oker, which is hard to digg, and the leaÅ¿t deepneÅ¿s is eight foot: I have my two Wrights Squaring of Timber for it, and I reÅ¿olve to have it a good HandÅ¿ome HouÅ¿e, Å¿ix Rooms off a floor, with a Study, two Å¿tories high above the Sellers, and the Garret above; And I doubt nor
if the FroÅ¿t bide away, but I Å¿hall have the Sellers finiÅ¿hed, and the geÅ¿ts laid above it, againÅ¿t the letter end of this moneth; for the Land that lyes to the houÅ¿e, I reÅ¿olve to fence in two Acres of it for an Orchard. and an Yeard, and to have hat done before the middle of February, and to have it planted with fruit trees; for I find a man in three years will have more Fruit in Å¿uch in Orchard then he kn â¢ ws how to make uÅ¿e of.

And about the middle of February, according as the Weather is, I reÅ¿olved to go out where I have tak â¢ n up my Land, which is upon a River, called the South-River, which is an exceeding pleaÅ¿ant River, and place, there goes onely with me â¢ here Mr David Violent. I can go from New- â¢ erth
â¢ o it in a Boat, in two houres and a half, let the wind blow as it will, and come ba â¢ k again in as much time; I wiÅ¿h I had as many Servants here as I could make uÅ¿e of. Any man that is â¢ rugal, and hath 300. lib. Sterling in Stock, to come over here, and bring over 7. or 8. g â¢ od Servants with him, I could aÅ¿Å¿ure him in 3. years time he Å¿h â¢ uld make a Å¿tock better then 1000. if not 1500. lib. if he beÅ¿tow his money right in Scotland, and take advice to bring all things here which is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for him to have in this Countrey. I am uncertain of the time I wil be at Home, but I reÅ¿olve you Å¿hall come over with me again, and ye will both think and Å¿ay, when ye Å¿ee the Countrey, that ye wiÅ¿h it had been done twenty years agoe. I thought it not fit to trouble my friends and relations; Å¿ince I could not write Å¿hort LettÃ¨rs to them, but any of them that deÅ¿ires to know the condition of this Countrey, ye may Å¿hew them this Letter, Å¿ince there is no Å¿ecret in it, you will find by William Burnets Letter, that he deÅ¿ires Å¿ome of his Sons to come over, and John Geddis
writs for Å¿ome of his Brethren; the which Letters cauÅ¿e deliver them carefully, and get an anÅ¿wer that if they be to come over, ye may Å¿peak for their paÅ¿Å¿age timely; he tells Å¿ome of them are good Wrights; which is all at preÅ¿ent, but keep a good heart to your Å¿elf, and take care of your Children, and I hope to Å¿ee you with more Comfort then we parted, and I am your ever loving Husband while I breath,

div.head: James JohnÅ¿ton of SpotÅ¿woods Letter to his Brother, John JohnÅ¿ton DrougeÅ¿t in Edinburgh.
div.p:
I Have taken up a part of my Land, 9. miles from Amboy, and 4. miles from PiÅ¿cataway, and as far from the neareÅ¿t part of Rariton, on a Brook Å¿ide, where there are exceeding great plains without any Timber, there is excellent Gunning for Dear and Turkies, of which there is great plenty, and eaÅ¿ily Å¿hot. But I reÅ¿olve to Å¿ee a place called Bernagate, which is 60. or 70. miles from this, on the SouthermoÅ¿t place of the Province, where there is a good River and Harbour, the beÅ¿t FiÅ¿hing and Gunning in any place in America 30. or 40. miles from any Plantation. The Indians here are nothing to be feared, the Place being as peaceable as any where elÅ¿e; I had occaÅ¿ion to travel through Long-IÅ¿land. and Stallen IÅ¿land, and for many miles found as many towns and plantations in the way, as in any Å¿o much Land in Louthean, there are no Bears
nor Ravinous BeaÅ¿ts but Wolves, which are nothing to be feared, neither are the Countrey People afraid to be among them all night, in Å¿o much as I oft-times going wrong, and lying out all night, and hearing their yells about me, and telling that I was afraid of them, the Countrey People laught at it; neither are the Snakes any thing to be noticed, for nothing can come near them, but they give warning with the ratling of their tail, Å¿o that People may either kill them, or go by them as they pleaÅ¿e. Oxen are Å¿o well taught that they go Å¿ometimes in a Plough, or Cart, without HorÅ¿e, or without a Gade-man; HorÅ¿es and Cattel are as cheap as in Scotland, conÅ¿idering their goodneÅ¿s and the difference of the Money; All Å¿orts of Scots goods Å¿ells well here, ye will be adviÅ¿ed with the next OccaÅ¿ion, what goods Å¿ells beÅ¿t in this place. I have great reaÅ¿on to thank GOD, that I am in a place which abundantly anÅ¿wers any thing I expected; The Air is healthful, and the Soil fruitful; the Indian Corn yeelds commonly 2. or 3. hundred fold, Oats 20. fold, as I am informed; the Indian Corn is an excellent grain, I have eat it and likes it very well in Pottage and Bread; there are Å¿everal reaÅ¿onable good towns in this Province, moÅ¿t of them hath more then eighty Families; there is no poor perÅ¿ons here, but all are half idle in reÅ¿pect of what they work with you. Flax twice heckled, Å¿old at 9. d. per pound, Wool is very cheap, only work is dear; the Liquor we moÅ¿t uÅ¿e is Sider; we have great Å¿tore of Fruit. In many places untaken up there are many plains and not a tree; I have never Å¿ince laÅ¿t parting had any Å¿ickneÅ¿s to keep me from one Dyet, for which I render thanks to GOD. The Indians here make it their trade to kill VeniÅ¿ion, and Å¿ell it to us: for a Å¿mal matter, I will have my Family Å¿erved with
FleÅ¿h all Winter; one of their SaÅ¿hiams, (which is their King) came to the Governour when I came firÅ¿t here, deÅ¿iring he might be Å¿uffered to trade amongÅ¿t us, and not to be beat out of our houÅ¿es, when they were drunk, but only that we might bind them, and permit them to cut timber, and Å¿ome Å¿uch things: At New-Perth, we have a good Stationers Shop of Books, the land is no where difficult to clear, albeit trees be 100. foot long and 3. or 4. foot over; I would heartily wiÅ¿h and perÅ¿wade any to come over that intends to live well, plentifuily and pleaÅ¿antly: Neither is there any TradeÅ¿man or Servant that could come wrong to this place, and I could wiÅ¿h my beÅ¿t friends no better but in the Å¿ame place with me; the old Inhabitants are a moÅ¿t careleÅ¿s and infrugall People, their profeÅ¿Å¿ion are moÅ¿t part ProteÅ¿tants, few Quakers, Å¿ome AnabaptiÅ¿ts, it is moÅ¿t deÅ¿ired there may be Å¿ome MiniÅ¿ters Å¿ent us over, they would have conÅ¿iderable Benefices, and good EÅ¿tates; and Å¿ince it would be a matter of great Piety, I hope ye will be inÅ¿trumentall to adviÅ¿e Å¿ome over to us, the place is aboundantly healthfull, as any elÅ¿e; there are a great difference betwixt the people here, who are Strong and Vigorous, and the people more Southerly in Mariland, we have great Å¿tore of VeniÅ¿ion which is Å¿ometimes as fat as Pork; one good Buck is Å¿old at 5. Å¿hil. and by the Indian at 2. Å¿hil. Oats are Å¿old at 18. pence the BuÅ¿hell; all Å¿orts of FiÅ¿h is here exceeding plentifull, the pooreÅ¿t PerÅ¿ons ea â¢ s no Meat that is Salt, except Pork; in Summer, they live much on Milk. I would no more value the Sea coming through if I had occaÅ¿ion, then ye would riding of of 20. miles; let me be rememberd to all friends, to Patrick Fortune who moÅ¿t carefuly diÅ¿Å¿waded me from this Voyage; which I doe not repent, but would
as carefully perÅ¿wade others, who Å¿tudy their own good; what I moÅ¿t earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ire of you, for the encouragment of this Plantation, is, you would be InÅ¿trumental to Å¿end us over Å¿ome MiniÅ¿ters, who I dare engadge Å¿hall afterwards ever be thankfull, and I oblidge to be your ever affectionate Broher,

opener.dateline: Amboy; or New-Perth in America, 9. of November, 1684.

div.p:
HAving accidently met with the Bearer, had not time to give you any particular accompt of this Countrey, only aÅ¿Å¿ure you, that it is beyond (not only) all our expectations, but all that ever you have heard Å¿poken of it, we (praiÅ¿ed be GOD) all of us arrived Å¿afely without the loÅ¿s of any on â¢ Pa â¢â¢â¢ ger; Å¿cacely any of them was ever Å¿ick, only we had much troubles coming from Mariland by land, our Skipper having for his own advantadge put in firÅ¿t at the Capes of Virginia; but we have had a brave ProÅ¿pect of the Countrey, and all the way as well as in this place where now we are, we found plenty of Corn, and all Kinds of Fruit, with FiÅ¿h, VeniÅ¿ion and wild Fowls, in Å¿uch abundance, that a Deer may be had for 2. Å¿hilling Countrey money, and Turkies for 6. pence, which will be at leaÅ¿t as big as any 2. Turkies in Scotland, and are realy Turkies only blacker then tame Turkies that you have Å¿een; I Å¿hall give you full Å¿atisfaction with the next occaÅ¿ion,
pray you fail not to writ to me, when you meet with any, otherwayes you diÅ¿oblidge him who is ever yours,

postscript.p: Writen to his Brother Munivard, in Scotland.

div.head: Patrick Falkconers Letter to Maurice Trent.

opener.dateline: Elizabeth Town in EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, the 28th. of October, 1684.

div.p:
MY laÅ¿t was dated the 22. Current, from Philadelphia, at which time I could give you but a Å¿mall account of the Countrey; and as yet its but a Å¿mall account, I can give by reaÅ¿on that I have had but a little time here as yet; I have travelled on Foot more then a 100. miles in EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t JerÅ¿ey, and PenÅ¿ilvania; I have alÅ¿o Travelled in Maryland, I cannot but Å¿ay it is a good Coun â¢â¢â¢ y, but its poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed with a Debauched, Idle, LeaÅ¿ie People, all that they Labour for is only as much Bread as Å¿erves them for one SeaÅ¿on, and als much Tobacco as may furniÅ¿h them with Cloaths, I believe it is the worÅ¿t improved countrey in the world; for the Indian wheat is that they truÅ¿t to, and if that fail them they may expect to Å¿tarve. I find PenÅ¿ilvania and the two JerÅ¿eyes are the places which Å¿et themÅ¿elves out moÅ¿t for Planting of Corn; As for the JerÅ¿ies I need not inÅ¿iÅ¿t in commending of them, for David Barclay and Arthur Forbes who had a longer Å¿tay here than I have had, will give you a more all account; for I intend to write no more than I
am able to make good. I may Å¿ay, that it is a pleaÅ¿ant Countrey, I did never Å¿ee more pleaÅ¿ant Meadows, and GraÅ¿s, then I have Å¿een in both the JerÅ¿ies, I have Å¿een plains of good Hay conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of about 30. Acres of ground, hardly one Tree to be Å¿een upon the whole Å¿pot. And there are Å¿everal places Å¿o; I can Å¿ay, its a well watered Countrey, and good waters, and if they were deÅ¿irous, they might have very good Quarrie here both for Stone of any Å¿ort, and Lime-Å¿tone likewiÅ¿e; but Å¿o long as Timber is Å¿o plenty, they will not be at the pains to Å¿eek after Stone; there are Å¿ome houÅ¿es in the Countrey built with Å¿tone, but very few. Having fallen in here, the end of the year, I cannot be capable to give an account what may be the product of the Countrey, but I hear that all Å¿orts of Grain hath very good IncreaÅ¿e, I Å¿ee the Countrey abounds with Apples, Quinches, Peatches, Walnuts, and ChaÅ¿nuts, and Strawberries in great abundance, wild-Wine-Grapes are plentifull, wild-Fowl of all Å¿orts, a great number of Deer, Turckie-Fowls-wild, in great abundance and very bigg, I have Å¿een theÅ¿e things in great plenty: I hope ye will excuÅ¿e me, becauÅ¿e I am not capable to give an ampler account of the Countrey, for I have not been two dayes in one place, I will tell you this is a good Countrey, for men who reÅ¿olves to be Laborious; any who comes here they muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to work hard for the firÅ¿t two or three years, till they get a little Ground cleared, for this muÅ¿t be looked on as a wood-Countrey, tho I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s the woods are not Å¿o thick as people expects; and there are Å¿everal places in the Countrey where there is little or no Wood; People are generally curious to have their Land near Navigable Rivers, but when they are better acquaint,
they will find that the farther back the better is the Land, there are aboundance of FiÅ¿h and OyÅ¿ters here, this is not a Countrey for idle people but Å¿uch as will be at pains, they need not doubt but to get Bread here in plenty, Å¿o I wiÅ¿h it be the Lords will that we may have a happy meeting again, his will be done, I wiÅ¿h you may be protected by the Lord, this from,

closer.signed: Your affectionate Friend, and humble, Servants Patrick Falconer.

div.head: AbÅ¿tract of a Letter writ by Peter WatÅ¿on (who went over a Servant with David Barclay, in the year 1683.) to John WatÅ¿on MeÅ¿Å¿enger in Selkirk.
div.p:
I Could never write to you before now, becauÅ¿e I was never rightly Å¿etled, and am not yet fully Å¿etled, but I am from among the reÅ¿t of the Servants, one James Reid and I and our Families are together, Å¿et out to a Farm on Amboy; we are to have Å¿ome Land laid out to us, and we are Stocked with two Mares, four Cowes, two Sows, two Oxen; my WiÅ¿e and I and the Child Richard are very well in health, and hath been Å¿o ever Å¿ince we came out of Scotland: Now as for this Countrey, it is a very good Countrey; indeed poor men Å¿uch as my Å¿elf, may live better here then in Scotland if they will but work, a man can have Corn and Cattle or any other Goods for his work, and he can Å¿ell theÅ¿e good to Å¿ome hands for money, it is not for a man that hath a Familie to come bound four years, but young men, who
have no trouble, they will do better to come and Å¿erve four years here then to Å¿erve in Scotland, for they are not Å¿o hard wrought as in Scotland, and when the four years are out, they can gain abundance to work to other men; or if they deÅ¿ire to Å¿etle upon Land of their own, they can have it reaÅ¿onably Cheap, the hardeÅ¿t work that is here, is clearing of the Ground, and felling of Trees, and the like; the firÅ¿t year is the worÅ¿t, till they be accuÅ¿tomed with the work of the Countrey, my Neighbour and I did clear from the middle of February till the midÅ¿t of May, five Acres of Land, and have it planted with Indian Corn, and Indian Beans, and Tobacco for our own Å¿moaking; a man who lives here needs go no where to buy any things, here he can have Corn and Cattle, and every thing that is neceÅ¿Å¿ar for mans uÅ¿e, if he be InduÅ¿trious, only the thing that is deareÅ¿t here, is Cloathing, for there are but few Sheep to this Countrey, but there are Å¿tore of all other BeaÅ¿ts, Å¿uch as HorÅ¿e; and Cows, and Hoggs, there is here good FiÅ¿hing, good hunting of Deer; and other kind of wild BeaÅ¿ts; The Countrey is very healthie as I have Å¿een yet, it is cold in the Winter like unto Scotland; But fra once the Summer breaks up, it is hotter then it is in Scotland; There are here very good Religious People, they go under the name of Independants, but are muÅ¿t like to the Prisbyterians, only they will not receive every one to their Society, we have great need of Good and Faithful MiniÅ¿ters; And I wiÅ¿h to God, that there would come Å¿ome over here, they can live as well, and have as much as in Scotland, and more then many gets; we have none within all this Province of EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, except one who is Preacher in Newwark; there were one or two Preachers more in the
Province; but they are dead; And now the people they meet together every Sabbath day, and Reads and Prays, and Å¿ings PÅ¿alms in their Meeting-houÅ¿es: this Countrey is very well Å¿ettled with People, moÅ¿t part of the firÅ¿t Settlers came out of New-England, very kind and loving people, kinder than in Scotland or England. And for the Indian Natives, they are not troubleÅ¿ome any way to any of us, if we do them no harm, but are a very kind and loving people; the men does nothing but hunts, and the women they plant Corn, and works at home; they come and trades among the ChriÅ¿tians with Skins or VeniÅ¿on, or Corn; or Pork; And in the Summer time, they and their Wives come down the Rivers, in their Cannoas, which they make themÅ¿elves of a piece of a great tree, like a little Boat, and rhere they FiÅ¿h and take OyÅ¿ters. This Countrey is a very pleaÅ¿ant Countrey with Rivers and Creiks to fiÅ¿h in; Only it is full of Wood, Å¿uch as Oak and Walnut-tree, CheÅ¿nut, Poplar, and Cedar; The only thing we want here is good People; I wiÅ¿h that all the poor Friends I or my Wife hath were here: As for my Brother, if he have a mind to come. Brother if you have but as much in the World as would tranÅ¿port you hither and your Family, I would deÅ¿ire you earneÅ¿tly to come, and bring my SiÅ¿ter with you; if you have as much as will tranÅ¿port you, Å¿ell all and come, tho you had not a penny after your paÅ¿Å¿age were payed, you need not fear if you have a mind to work; I was as little brought up with work as any man, yet bleÅ¿Å¿ed be GOD, I can work now as my Neighbors, and lives very contentedly with my Wife better then ever we did in Scotland; Å¿hew my Mother in Law tha â¢ my Wife and I would be very well pleaÅ¿ed, if Å¿he would
come over, there are as old Women as Å¿he com â¢â¦ here out of old England; there was one came alongÅ¿t with us elder then Å¿he, if Å¿he will come, Å¿he Å¿hall live with her Daughter and me, as eaÅ¿ie, and as well as ever Å¿he did live in Scotland; and I do know that was well enough; my Wife and I are well at preÅ¿ent, as you could wiÅ¿h, GOD be bleÅ¿Å¿ed; I can Å¿ay no more, but my love to my Brother, and his wife, and all Friends,

closer.signed: I reÅ¿t your loving CuÅ¿in, Peter WatÅ¿on.

div.head: A Letter write by John Campbel to John Dobie.
div.p:
I Wrote a line from Philadelphia to you, as we were coming hither, your CuÅ¿in James Dobbie the bearer is in Å¿uch haÅ¿te, that I cannot write what I would Å¿ay; but is Å¿hort, we are come here to a good wholeÅ¿ome Countrey, in which with little induÅ¿trie a man may have a comfortable life; there is good Wheat and Oats growing here, and Indian Corn, which our Servants likes very well; There is FiÅ¿h and Fowl abundance, and of Cows and HorÅ¿e; they labour wi h HorÅ¿e and Oxen; There is Deer through all the Countrey, and Turkies which Å¿ome of our Servants has killed a part of already; There is Pertrages and Quails very rife, that my wife yeÅ¿terday morning Å¿aw about 20. of them walking before the door like Chikens. I Å¿hall Å¿ay no more till I Å¿ee farther, for I am
with others going to the Countrey on Munday to Å¿ee for the Countrey lotts; for I have taken up the Towns already, and cut down the trees of two Acres of ground with Å¿ix men in three dayes, My Å¿ervice to all Friends, I am

closer.signed: Your moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ured Friend, John Campbel.

div.head: A Letter from Thomas Fullerton Brother to the Laird of Kinnaber, to his Brother in Law Doctor Gordon in MontroÅ¿s.
div.p:
BY my laÅ¿t about a Moneth Å¿ince I dated from Amboy, you underÅ¿tand that we came to Sandy-Hook, 18. weeks after we Å¿ailed from Montrofe, we were 9. weeks at Sea from Killebeg in Ireland, we had many croÅ¿s winds, what other accidents we met with by the way were worth the telling, but not the writting; bleÅ¿Å¿ed be God we all kept our healths very well, only one Boy fell over boord; what you expect, and I deÅ¿ign by this, is a breef, but true accompt, of the Country. The firÅ¿t land we diÅ¿covered was About the midle of Long-IÅ¿land, it appeared at firÅ¿t like trees, growing out of the Sea, Towards night we Anchored in Sandy-Hooke; The land is low and levell, that is the reaÅ¿on we were within 8. or 10. mile thereof, before we Å¿aw it; the country appears all over Woodie; I landed on a Å¿andie-bank and cloÅ¿s by the flood march, where grew Bayes, Å¿aÅ¿Å¿afax and Å¿everall prettie Å¿hrubs I knew not; The Woods conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of Å¿everall kinds of Oaks, CheÅ¿nut, Hickacy, Walnut, Poplar, and Beetch, Cedars grow on Å¿wamps, and barrens Firrs and Pines only on barrens; The ground generally is 2. or 3. inches
deep of black dung as it were, below that is reediÅ¿h mould, what you heard of the product of the Indian Corn, viz. 100. or 200. fold, of 20 or 30 fold, IngliÅ¿h wheat, of the abundance of dears and wild horÅ¿e, and Å¿everall turkies and of the great plenty of fiÅ¿hes are all true; There is very much Cider here. In 12. or 14. years you may make 100. barrells from your own planting, the beÅ¿t fleÅ¿hes of all kinds ever I did Å¿ee are here, tho this in reÅ¿pect of what you have heard, be generally tautollogie; yet I found my Å¿elf oblidged to writ it, becauÅ¿e I am witneÅ¿s to the truth thereof, without Hyperbole.

NotwithÅ¿tanding of all this, its very troubleÅ¿ome expenÅ¿ive to Å¿ettle a plantation here, and when it is done, I cannot promiÅ¿e you a man will grow verry rich; but he needs want nothing, and it is not every one will agree with the Å¿olitude of the Woods, theÅ¿e who can, and reÅ¿olve to lead an countty life, cannot doe better then come hither; a merchant who will come over and Å¿et up Å¿tore in the country, for a year will make cent per cent; of Å¿everal commodities with which I doe allow none to be acquainted but commerads. I wiÅ¿h I had Å¿ome money of my Å¿tock Å¿o imployed, and Å¿ent Å¿afely here, JohnÅ¿touns of Å¿poiÅ¿wood, and I haue taken up upon a river, 6, or 8. miles in Amboy, your Brother Thomas and Robert, are here alÅ¿o, Å¿ervants are not eaÅ¿ily intertained here, I deÅ¿igned to have Å¿hot als many Å¿quirles as would have furred a coa â¢ for you, but I am otherwiÅ¿e taken up; I have omitted to tell you that the weather here is conÅ¿tantly clear, the Å¿un riÅ¿es and Å¿etts free of clouds; I have obÅ¿eved none to have the cough in this country tho I have frequently lyne in the woods; aboundance of fire is an excellent counter charm. Now brother as to your own coming over,
it will be time to invite you, when I have a good houÅ¿e, and inter â¢ ainment to treat you with unbought; for you muÅ¿t not feel any of the inconveniencies I have met with; we are all well, I pray God, this may find you alÅ¿o; preÅ¿ent my Å¿ervice to all friends, Male or Femal; this letter wil Å¿erve that, preÅ¿ent my Å¿ervice to my Grand-Mother; upon ChriÅ¿tmaÅ¿s I drank her good-health in Rhumb Madera, and Fial Wine; If I can be frugall, I may be Å¿oon rich here; by my next I hope to enÅ¿ure 60, or 70. lib: to the perÅ¿on, for we want a miniÅ¿ter, this from,

div.head: A Letter from the Å¿ame hand to the Laird of BrotherÅ¿toun in the Mairns, of the Å¿ame date.
div.p: YOu were pleaÅ¿ed Å¿o kindly to concern your Å¿elf with my welfare when I was by you (and I find that abÅ¿ence augments true friendÅ¿hip) that I am oblidged to acquaint you with my preÅ¿ent fortune, which I hope Å¿hall be far better then what I could expect, by Å¿o much Å¿tock in Scotland. This place is not altogether bowriÅ¿h; for at New-York you may have railing and Gallanting enough, the inhabitants are generally great Å¿penders. Dear Brothertoun writ to me, and give me an accompt of affairs, for I aÅ¿Å¿ure you, neither Governour nor Council will medle with yours to me, nor mine to you; by my next I will writ to Cl â¢ nie, and John JohnÅ¿toun; in the mean time preÅ¿ent my Å¿ervice to them, I am in haÅ¿te to end writing, tho ever being,

closer.signed: Your Oblidged Commerad and humble Å¿ervant, Tho: Fullertoun

div.head: AbÅ¿tract of a Letter from Robert Hardie, Merchant in Aberdeen, to his Son John Hardie Merchant there, dated from Elizabeth-Town, the 8. of December, 1684.
div.p:
I Have writ two Letters already to you at our arrival, an other Å¿hewing the death of your Brother William, and Å¿omething of the country; but knowes not if they be come to your hands, and now having this occaÅ¿ion, know that I am in good health, and your Brother Alexander, praiÅ¿ed be God, know that I intend to reÅ¿ide here, and Å¿hould wiÅ¿h that I had all my childring with me, but your conveniencie cannot permit, neith â¢ r am I able to transport them as yet; however I deÅ¿ire you to acquaint your Å¿iÅ¿ter ElÅ¿peth that I deÅ¿ire her to come over if poÅ¿Å¿ible, with her firÅ¿t conveniencie; I in â¢ end before her coming to have a new houÅ¿e in New-Perth, and a Plantation near by it; if I had gott an good accompt of that Litle cargo I Å¿ent over; I would have lived upon it here, als well as upon 100 lib. Sterling in Scotland; But I have got an bad accompt of it; how ever, I hope to Provide for you all with what is left, if the Lord bleÅ¿s; Shew my brother and brothers in law, that if they would come over with each of them two Servants, they could have good Land here, at one eaÅ¿ie rate, they might live better then their maÅ¿ters; and with leÅ¿s trouble, if they took but half the pains; They take in Scotland; for the Land is an brave and plentifull Land; Shew Andrew and David Hardies that if they can but pay their PaÅ¿Å¿age and come to me, I Å¿hall make them to live in better condition then ever formerly; I doubt not but Å¿ome of our neighbours will come over, to bring
Servants here, who will give you an true accompt how, I and others can live here; believ â¢ me, this is an brave Land, and any who will be InduÅ¿trous, may live very comfortably here; He who comes firÅ¿t will have the beÅ¿t choiÅ¿e, and moÅ¿t profitable as for idle-men who will neither work nor trade, need never come here, for there are none idle here, I wiÅ¿h you all a bliÅ¿ing from God, and Å¿o reÅ¿ts,

div.head: A Letter from James JohnÅ¿ton of Spotswood, to his brother John JohnÅ¿ton, dated the 13. of February, 1685. from PiÅ¿catta way, in EaÅ¿t-New-JerÅ¿ey.
div.p:
THeÅ¿e are to remember my kindeÅ¿t affection to you, my Mother, and all friends, we have kept our healths hither to exceeding well, Have endured an Å¿hort hut very cold witner, now the Weather hath been for Å¿ome time bygone exceeding good, was an Bear-Å¿eed Å¿eaÅ¿on with you; I have been throw Å¿everal or moÅ¿t places of this Countrey, of late; But am not yet reÅ¿olved where my firÅ¿t Husbandry Å¿hall be; the Land is exceeding good, which is yet to take up, much better then what is inhabited; only not Å¿o convenient; the difficulty of clearing many places is no wayes conÅ¿iderable; I find Land where Several hundered Plughes may be preÅ¿ently Å¿et a work, I take all pains I can to be conveniently Å¿etled, and the Governour refuÅ¿es us nothing we deÅ¿ire; I Å¿tand in need of 40. pound, value of good, and Å¿ome Servants;
hoping to have Corn for them, and others who come over; I could wiÅ¿h your Å¿elf were here, we could live competently and quietly; but I doubt how affairs may premit; I wiÅ¿h any Land I had were Å¿old, that you might he furthered; preÅ¿en â¢ my love and Å¿ervice to my Motherâª and SiÅ¿ter whom I hope to Å¿ee here; I wiÅ¿h you would Å¿end over Å¿ome MiniÅ¿ters, one or moe to us I am,

div.p: NOw Sir, does not the peruÅ¿al of thir Letters, obliege you to believe there is no deceit in the above written diÅ¿cription of the place, Å¿eeing you find the Å¿ame Homollogat by Å¿o many different perÅ¿ons; the Hollograph of moÅ¿t of them have been peruÅ¿ed by many perÅ¿ons in this City, and are to be Å¿een by any inquiÅ¿itive thereanent at Captain Hamiltouns Lodging at the Sign of the Ship, for their more Å¿atisfaction of the truth thereof.

But tho you appear to be convinced, that EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey is in it Å¿elf a very deÅ¿irable place, and conÅ¿equently upon Å¿everal conÅ¿iderations a very proper Å¿eat
for a Collony; From this yet I have ground to conjecture from Å¿ome tacit hints and inÅ¿inuations in yours, that becauÅ¿e WeÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, PenÅ¿ilvania, and in a Å¿pecial manner Carolina, are more Å¿outherly, therefore you think there is Å¿ome ground to believe they may have the advantage of the Soyl, Å¿eing you oblidge me to tell you freely my opinion in this affair, I will be plain with you; the two firÅ¿t lying, the one upon the one Å¿ide of the River of Delawar, the other upon the other Å¿ide thereof, may have in themÅ¿elves other advantages; but I cannot be Å¿o blind, when I notice the Mapp, as not to diÅ¿cover too palpable an inconveniencie to be paÅ¿t over; wherewith both the Å¿aid Countries are much Å¿traitned; to wit. the Town of NewcaÅ¿tle lying upon the mouth of the River, which doth Å¿o abÅ¿olutly command the River, that whoÅ¿oever is maÅ¿ter thereof, may if they pleaÅ¿e, lay what impoÅ¿ition they think fit upon both the Å¿aid Countries; Å¿eeing if any difference Å¿hould fall betwixt the Town of NewcaÅ¿tle, and the PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors, or Inhabitants of theÅ¿e two Provinces, they may make themÅ¿elves very quickly MaÅ¿ters
of them, by impoÅ¿ing what conditions they think fit upon them; Å¿eeing no. Ship can either conveniently go up or down the Å¿aid River of Delawar, but by allowance of any Fort, built upon the Å¿aid Town of NewcaÅ¿tle: Whatever opinion others may have of this as a matter of no great import, I have theÅ¿e Å¿entiments of the apparent inconveniencies thereof, as after perceiving it never to be any more Å¿o much concerned, as to make farther inquiry after theÅ¿e places Å¿eeing in my apprehenÅ¿ion, no advantage to be propoÅ¿ed there could compenÅ¿e that Å¿o viÅ¿ible conveniency.

As for Carolina, I confeÅ¿s it is nothing Å¿trange that any perÅ¿on who hath read Ogibies deÅ¿cription thereof in his America and WilÅ¿ons in his TreatiÅ¿e thereanent; Judge it in a maner a TerreÅ¿tiral ParadiÅ¿e, but notwithÅ¿tanding of all this, err you paÅ¿s any judgement upon my choiÅ¿ing rather EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, then Carolina for the Å¿eat of a Collony from this, allow me to give my ReaÅ¿ons why I do prefer the one to the other.

We lye here in 56. Degrees of Northren Latitude, JerÅ¿ey in 41. Carolina in 31. it is very obvious to any underÅ¿tanding perÅ¿on, that our removall to 41. is more probably contributive for our health, then to 31, being ten degrees hotter; and conÅ¿equently more dangerous, what ever opinion others may have of this, I judge it a matter of no Å¿mal conÅ¿equence, health being very much preferrable to all other things whatÅ¿oever.

But further, our acceÅ¿s to EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey is very patent, no apparent obÅ¿truction in the way, whereas the coaÅ¿t of Carolina is the moÅ¿t dangerous in all America, there being a bank of Å¿and lying all along the Å¿ame for 200. Leags and upwards, Å¿o that the entry to any part thereof is altogether hazardous, we have too Å¿ad a proof of the truth of this, by the Shipwrack of the James of Air, upon that bank this laÅ¿t HarveÅ¿t, in which were loÅ¿t upwards of 60. peop â¢ e.

Experience alÅ¿o teacheth that the Clymate of JerÅ¿ey, is far move Å¿uitable to our ConÅ¿titutions, then that of Carolina;
You find in all the Letters come from JerÅ¿ey, this one particular Å¿pecially marked, That it is a very healthfull Air; no complaints of Å¿ickneÅ¿s there, whereas in the few Letters from our Countrey men Å¿ettled in Carolina; You have an accompt of the death of the greateÅ¿t part who went hence to that place.

There is one further conÅ¿ideration oblidging me altogether, to cloÅ¿e my Ears and Eyes againÅ¿t Carolina; whatever Å¿pecious pretences may flie abroad in favours thereof, and be received by Å¿uch who are not concerned, to enquire further, then to hear-Å¿ay, and that is the conÅ¿ideration of the model of their Government, then which nothing can be more diÅ¿couraging to any having the Å¿ence of a rational Man, or Spirit of a Gentleman. The Offices of Honour and TruÅ¿t, Å¿uch, as Chancellour, TheÅ¿aurer, Admiral, Secretar, &c. are all Heretably annexed to the Proprietors; by the conÅ¿titution of their Government, Å¿o that let a Gentleman deÅ¿erve never Å¿o well, however eminent his parts may be, he muÅ¿t in the firÅ¿t place purchaÅ¿e a property, err he can attain to any of theÅ¿e places of
TruÅ¿t, or Honor; whereas if you have Å¿o much Money as to make this purchaÅ¿e, you may then come to theÅ¿e preferments though you were the arrenteÅ¿t Block head in nature! Money here makes you capable of Preferment, which neither Vertue, Merit, nor parts can do! Can there be a greater diÅ¿couragement to any perÅ¿on of Spirit or Honour, than to go Å¿ubject himÅ¿elf to a Government where he Å¿ees himÅ¿elf debarred of any TruÅ¿t or Preferment, how ever deÅ¿erving he may be? unleÅ¿s he hath money in a manner to buy it with. Both in this Kingdom and our Neighbour Nations, we Å¿ee mean PerÅ¿ons have by their Parts and Merit raiÅ¿ed themÅ¿elves to places of the higheÅ¿t Preferments in the Kingdoms, and have diÅ¿charged that TruÅ¿t conferred upon them with Honour and ApplauÅ¿e; So that when I have this conÅ¿ideration before my Eyes, I muÅ¿t conclude any who Å¿ubjects themÅ¿elves to that model of Government, are either ignorant of the ConÅ¿titutions thereof, or of very mean Spirits, to Å¿ettle themÅ¿elves in a place where Vertue nor Merit can neither raiÅ¿e them, nor their PoÅ¿terity!

Let me add another Ground of my diÅ¿Å¿atisfaction with the Model of that Government, and you may judge whether the Å¿ame be reaÅ¿onable or not; There are eight Proprietors by their ConÅ¿titutions, it appears clear to me, that they are Å¿o many Soveraigns, Å¿eing by one expreÅ¿s Article of their Fundamental ConÅ¿titutions, it is declared, That the Proprietors are no waves Å¿ubject to Law, in Å¿o far as to be cenÅ¿ured by any Judicatur there; So that be their Actings never Å¿o Illegal, or unjuÅ¿t; if any theÅ¿e eight Proprietors Å¿hould commit Murders, or Rapes, or any other Act of OppreÅ¿Å¿ion, they cannot be challenged upon accompt thereof in any Judicatory in Carolina.

TheÅ¿e being Å¿o matterial Objections, I need not add the apparent hazard of being next Neighbour to the Spainard, whoÅ¿e intereÅ¿t it is to ruine any Å¿etling at Port Royal; how little probability there is, that any going at firÅ¿t from this can be of Å¿ufficient Å¿trength to defend themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t their deÅ¿igns, that in caÅ¿e of any aÅ¿Å¿ault from that airth; their nixt and only neighbour, Charles-toun,
could not give that help, which were requiÅ¿it in Å¿uch an exigent, either againÅ¿t the Spainards their nixt neighbours, at St. AuguÅ¿tines Fort, or the Natives, if they Å¿hould become quarrelÅ¿ome Neighbors; But from the complext conÅ¿ideration of all together, I muÅ¿t diveÅ¿t my Å¿elf of my reaÅ¿on, or I judge Carolina a proper Å¿eat to Å¿ettle my Å¿elf in.

But tho you be oblidged to grant, that EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, may be the moÅ¿t deÅ¿irable Å¿pott of ground upon the continent of America for Å¿uch a deÅ¿ign, upon the above written conÅ¿iderations; yet I do apprehend you may incline to think that Tobago, St. Luce, St. Vincent, or Å¿ome of theÅ¿e IÅ¿lands were yet more proper as affoording at firÅ¿t view greater ground of expecting Å¿uitable returns to the apparent expenÅ¿e & hazards of Å¿uch a undertaking; witneÅ¿s the great riches of Barbadoes, by the improvment of a Trade, from that place all Europe over.

In anÅ¿wer to this, I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, Sir, that there may be greater improvements of Å¿uch IÅ¿lands as to trade, when they do come to that length of improvement, as to produce Suggars, Cotton,
Indigo, &c. But let me alÅ¿o tell you, there is a certain proÅ¿pect of far greater & more imminent hazards in Å¿ettling there, then in EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey. It is certainly obvious to the meaneÅ¿t capacities what hardÅ¿hips theÅ¿e muÅ¿t be oblidged to lay their compt to meet with who would interpriÅ¿e Å¿uch a deÅ¿ign, not only from the wants thy might be expoÅ¿ed to throw lake of neceÅ¿Å¿ar Å¿upplies, wherewith they cannot expect the conveniencie of being furniÅ¿hed. but from other hazards and difficulties. It is not Å¿mall Å¿tock could Å¿et Å¿uch a deÅ¿ing on foot, neither can it be expected that Å¿uch who would ingadge in Å¿uch undertaking from this place could in many years attain to that Å¿trength, which were neceÅ¿Å¿arily requiÅ¿ite for defending themÅ¿elves even againÅ¿t the Piracy of a Buccanier or two, far leÅ¿s againÅ¿t the invaÅ¿ions or aÅ¿Å¿aults of forraign States and Princes.

As for my own part I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, I am not very anxious of great Riches, as the reÅ¿ult of this undertaking, but to carry my Wife and Children with me; I am bound the beÅ¿t I can to look to their Accommodation; when I land in EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey
there are Lodgings, and all other neceÅ¿Å¿ars to be had for money, till by our own induÅ¿try in Labouring the Ground, we provide for our Å¿elves, which could not be expected in one of theÅ¿e IÅ¿lands; If I have a Countrey no worÅ¿e than the South of France, with theÅ¿e Conveniencies above narrated, I deÅ¿ire no richer Soyl; though greater expectations might be had of the reÅ¿ult of Å¿uch a deÅ¿ign of Å¿etling in one of theÅ¿e IÅ¿lands, as to Profit and Gain, when once come the length of a good Trade.

But beÅ¿ides this, our Countrey People which will be the Å¿trength of any Collony, to go from this place, knows very well how to labour the Ground, for producing all Å¿orts of Grains, after what faÅ¿hion, to breed abundance of all Å¿orts of BeÅ¿tial, in both which, will the great riches of JerÅ¿ey conÅ¿iÅ¿t; But it cannot he expected, that they know how to improve theÅ¿e IÅ¿lands, for Suggar, Cotton, Indigo, &c. and this being altogether out of their road, we Å¿hould thus be altogether deprived of the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance we may rationally expect from them, by propoÅ¿ing to Å¿ettle in a place where the Nigro Slaves could do more Å¿ervice, and
be far more uÅ¿efull than the moÅ¿t laboriousâª and judicious of our Countrey People.

As for the ordinar Objection againÅ¿t Å¿etling in JerÅ¿ey, upon account of the inconveniencies may ariÅ¿e from having a Governour of Principles alledged inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with the Å¿tanding of any Society; upon this one head mentioning no other, that a man who profeÅ¿Å¿es, he judges it unlawful to draw his Å¿word to defend himÅ¿elf againÅ¿ â¢ a Na ive, if he were coming to cut his throat, can never be Å¿o careful in providing Å¿uch certain and Å¿peedy remedies for preventing any hazard that way, as are abÅ¿olutely requiÅ¿ite for the Å¿ecurity of theÅ¿e who Å¿ettle there, both againÅ¿t any DeÅ¿igns of the Natives or Forraign InvaÅ¿ions. This is very eaÅ¿ily anÅ¿wered, that there being Å¿everal very Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Citizens of London concerned in this Plantation, who are not of this Principle, who have laid out conÅ¿iderable Å¿umms on this DeÅ¿ign, as I am oblidged to know by the accompt I have from one of them, with whom I have Å¿ome correÅ¿pondence; who tells me, he himÅ¿elf hath laid out 1800. pound; It cannot rationally be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed that they will be Å¿o unconcerned, as not to follow Å¿uch meaÅ¿ures as may Å¿ecure what intereÅ¿t they have there; Methods
are already laid down, which I know will Å¿atisfie you in this particular, that as to defence againÅ¿t any Å¿uch inconveniencies; EaÅ¿t JerÅ¿ey will be as effectually Å¿ecured as any of the Neighbouring Plantations.

As for any other ApprehenÅ¿ions you or others may have upon this head, I Å¿hall only Å¿ay, what ever Mr. Barclays Principles may be, he is a Gentleman known to be abundantly qualified to advance the intereÅ¿t of that Collony, elÅ¿e the TruÅ¿t thereof had not been devolved upon him by the Proprietors, who are Men more knowing in their own Affairs, then to have made an eÅ¿cape in Å¿o matterial a point; they are Men abundantly Å¿harpÅ¿ighted to remark his Actions, and accordingly as they find them for the intereÅ¿t of the place, to continue him in that TruÅ¿t or not; And you may be aÅ¿Å¿ured, he underÅ¿tands himÅ¿elf Å¿o well, as to behave himÅ¿elf in that Å¿tation Å¿o as becometh a Gentleman, concerned in his own Credit and IntereÅ¿t, Å¿eing upon the leaÅ¿t malverÅ¿ation, he is als well â¢ vable to cenÅ¿ure of the Law, as the meaneÅ¿t Inhabitant. Which conÅ¿ideration abundantly Å¿ecures
any reaÅ¿onable Man againÅ¿t the ApprehenÅ¿ions of any inconveniencie from his being Governour, tho his inclinations prompted him to act upon a Å¿elfiÅ¿h deÅ¿ign, to the prejudice of the general intereÅ¿t of that Province, I perÅ¿wade my Å¿elf, he is more a Gentleman, than ever to be guilty of any thing that is baÅ¿e, or unbecoming a Gentleman.

It is now more then time to bid you farewel, having nothing further to add, hoping from what is here Å¿aid, you will reÅ¿t Å¿atisfied, that in proÅ¿ecuting this deÅ¿ign, I do act upon Å¿olid foundations, let the reÅ¿ult be what it will; I hope you are convinced I have not proceeded indeliberatly therein; I am not Å¿o fooliÅ¿h as to propoÅ¿e no difficulties to my Å¿elf to be rancountered, notwithÅ¿tanding all the incouragements above written, I am too well acquainted with all the SpaniÅ¿h, French, Dutch, Portugues, & EngliÅ¿h undertakings of this nature, and their Å¿taits and difficulties they have been tryÅ¿ted with in proÅ¿ecuting thereof, to think I have any ground to expect to be altogether exeemed from all the inconveniencies they met with; as to this I caÅ¿t my Å¿elf altogether upon the divine Providence, being convinced, I am in my duty; if you pleaÅ¿e to
take a Å¿hare, it would be not a little incouraging to me, you Å¿ee that we have Å¿ome Gentlemen of our Countrey Å¿ettled already there; Å¿o that I am hopefull we may have there a very agreeable Å¿ociety if your affairs cannot allow, your good wiÅ¿hes are expected by,

div.p:
I Hope you have heard of our Voyage and Å¿afe Arrival here, I thought it my duty to preÅ¿ent my dutiful reÅ¿pects to you and all Friends at
Aberdeen, and to acquaint you of mine own and all their welfares who came over the laÅ¿t year,, all which intends to Å¿ettle in the Countrey, except _____ who has Å¿pent all his means already fooliÅ¿hly on drink, and is returning home for more; you have David Barclay and Arthur Forbes to inform you of this Countrey; when I have Å¿een it through all the SeaÅ¿ons of the year as they did, I Å¿hall then give you my opinion, if you be deÅ¿irous; only in Å¿hort, what I have Å¿een I may write, that it pleaÅ¿es me better then Virginia, Maryland, PenÅ¿ilvania, or WeÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, that it is pleaÅ¿ant to mine eyes, and I find it healthful to my body; I am not troubled here (bleÅ¿Å¿ed be GOD) with defl â¢ ctions, head-aikes, and coughs, as at Edinburgh; that the land is furniÅ¿hed with all conveniencies â¢ f Nature, Å¿uch as Wood, GraÅ¿s, M â¢ adow, and abundance of freÅ¿h Water Springs, Brooks and Rivers, and plenty of Deer, Turkies, GeeÅ¿s and Dukes; many tender H â¢ rbs, Fruits, and Trees grow naturally here that will not grow in Scotland at all; theÅ¿e things are Å¿o notoriouÅ¿ly known, that it is Å¿uperfluity to write them, and no unbyaÅ¿sed perÅ¿on will deny them, or Å¿peak ill of the land: There is about a duzon of 14. houÅ¿es in New-Perth, and the half of thoÅ¿e built Å¿ince we
came, Å¿everal others are building preÅ¿ently, and many others have taken Lotts to build; Mr. Mudie is building a Å¿tone houÅ¿e, and has an HorÅ¿e Mill ready to Å¿et up; Governour Rudyeard intends another Stone houÅ¿e this Summer; The Governours houÅ¿e, and the publick Court-houÅ¿e are abuilding; It is the beÅ¿t Å¿cituate for a City of any yet I have Å¿een, or for ought I can learn of any yet known in America. There is great encouragement here for all kind of TradÅ¿men; I intend my Å¿elf to follow moÅ¿tly Planting and FiÅ¿hing; Let this remember me to all my Friends, Relations, Comorads and Acquaintances at Aberdeen; I could not write to them all, being buÅ¿ied about mine own Å¿etlement, and it is now far, Å¿pent in the year, Å¿o that I do not expect to do much this year, neither could I Å¿ettle Å¿ooner, by reaÅ¿on that my bed-cloaths are not yet come from Maryland; and the land I intend to Å¿ettle on is not yet purchaÅ¿ed from the Indians. I intreat to hear from you on all occaÅ¿ions, and what remarkable News abroad or at home, and how the CiviliÅ¿ts place is diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of; my Å¿ervice to your Å¿elf and bedfellow, I am,

closer.signed: Your moÅ¿t affectionat and humble Servant, Charles Gordon.
