div.p:
I SuppoÅ¿e ye have heard of our voyage from my Brother, and Governour Barclay; I Å¿hall only in Å¿hort tell you that notwithÅ¿tanding the loÅ¿s of our maÅ¿ts, we were only 8. weeks betwixt land and land, and entered the Capes of Virginia the Å¿ame day 9. weeks we parted from Aberdeen. We Å¿ailed up CheÅ¿Å¿apeck bay to the head of Bohemia-River in 2. Å¿lowpes, from thence we came to Elizabeth-Town, partly by Land and partly by Water, the Å¿torm being the tail of a Hurricane, was not univerÅ¿all, for we heard of no Ships which met with it but our Å¿elves; nor the MontroÅ¿e Ship did not meet with it. There is incouragement for Å¿everal trades here, in the firÅ¿t place Planting, for Wheat, Indian Corn; Beef, Pork, &c. give all ready money in York, and the Neighbour Collonies; Wheat 4. Å¿hillings the
buÅ¿hel, Indian Corn 2. Å¿s. or half a crown, Pork and Beef, &c. to be had at an ordinary eaÅ¿ie rate. And in the Å¿econd place there may be FiÅ¿hing; For the Inhabitants averr they Å¿wim Å¿o thick in the Creeks and Rivers, at certain Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the year, that they have hailed them out of the waters with their very hand. In the third place for one to have a Malt-houÅ¿e, a brew houÅ¿e, and a bake-houÅ¿e, to make Malt, brew beer, and bake biÅ¿keet for Barbadoes and the Neighbour Collonies, providing he have a Å¿hip of his own, and Å¿kill to manage his buÅ¿ines, would certainly be a good trad. LaÅ¿tly for one to buy up the product of the Countrey, Å¿uch as all kinds of grains, Beef, Pork, &c. and export them to Barbadoes, and import Rumm and MalaÅ¿Å¿es, would certainly be a good trade; as likewiÅ¿e change keeping wold be a good trad in Amboy, for the higheÅ¿t deÅ¿igne of the old Buckskine Planters (I am juÅ¿t now drinking to one of them; our Countrey man who was Å¿ent away by Cromvel to New-England, a Å¿lave from Dumbar, Living now in Woodbridge, Like a Scots Laird, wiÅ¿hes his Countrey men and Native Soyle very well, though he never intends to Å¿ee it. Pardon this ParentheÅ¿is) is to acquite a piece of monie to drink
in the change houÅ¿e. This Countrey, and particularly this Town (Å¿howeth it to be the beÅ¿t Å¿cituated for a city of any there known in America) is but yet in infancie (it not being above 48. years at moÅ¿t Å¿ince ever there was a Planter in the Province; & that occaÅ¿ioned by their changing Å¿o many MaÅ¿ters) yet there are Å¿everal thouÅ¿ands of People already, and not want of good company, and if ye pleaÅ¿e badd too, as in any place of the world; neither are we altogether deÅ¿titut of Books and Clergy, for George Keith, (who arrived three weeks Å¿ince with others, they were all winter in Borbadoes) hath brought Mathematicks, and Benjamin Clark a Librarie of Books, to Å¿ell; Å¿o that you may Å¿ee New Perth begins to be founded upon Clergy. Shew my CuÅ¿ins, George-Burnet, and Richard Maitland, that I hope they will not laugh more at me, for Å¿aying, â¢ n Edinburgh, I would line my houÅ¿e with Cedar-wood, for all houÅ¿es here are covered with Cedar; and one juÅ¿t now built in Perth, altogether of Cedar-Wood, it is reckoned a wood of no value here, except for its laÅ¿tineÅ¿s. I intend to follow Planting my Å¿elf, and if I had but the Å¿mall Stock here I have in Scotland, with Å¿ome more Å¿ervants,
I would not go home to Aberdeen for a Regencie, as was profered me; neither do I intend it however, hoping, to get my own Å¿afe over; we are not troubled here leading our pitts, mucking our Land, and Ploughing 3. times; one Plouing with 4. or 6. Oxen at firÅ¿t breaking up; and with 2. horÅ¿e only thereafter, Å¿uffices for all; you may judge whither, that be eaÅ¿ier Husbandrie than in Scotland; But I know you are no good Husband-man. But which of the foreÅ¿aid trades you will choice, if you will come here you Å¿elf is more then I can divine, or will adviÅ¿e you to; I have told you how things are, and in Gods-Name take your own choice, as I have done. I Å¿hall tell you what I would do, were I in your place, if it Å¿hall fall out you do come, I would get Å¿ome truÅ¿ty Comorads, Merchants to joyn with me, and Å¿ett up a trade in Perth, for I think a mans own trade fitts him beÅ¿t; if you have 5000. Merks it is enough, 4. in goods and one in money, Let none come here deÅ¿titute of money, it is of great requeÅ¿t here, and gets chape Penyworths, and 25. per cent of advantage by it; but I doe not adviÅ¿e you, for if you Å¿hould meet with Å¿uch trouble and diÅ¿opoyntments as we have done by being put by our PoÅ¿t, you would perhapps be diÅ¿couraged,
& give me the blame; all our baggadg is not yet come from Maryland, and I want yet my bed Cloathes, and the Land I intend to Å¿ettle on is not yet purchaÅ¿Å¿ed from the Indians; for after I have viewed all the Province Å¿uch of it as is yet habitable, I have choÅ¿en the South branch of Rariton-River for conveniency of FiÅ¿hing, Fowling, and Meadow, but all the beÅ¿t Land lyes back from the Rivers and the Sea CoÅ¿ts; the further back the better it is, which neceÅ¿Å¿itates me to go a mile back. In breif what you heard of the countrey is all true, Å¿o I need not Å¿pine out long DiÅ¿criptions of it; no unbyaÅ¿Å¿ed and indifferent PerÅ¿on will Å¿peak ill of the Land, it is both pleaÅ¿ant and wholeÅ¿ome, and induÅ¿trous People, after Å¿ome few years Labour, may lead a pleaÅ¿ant, eaÅ¿ie Life, and want for nothing; And I am of opinion, may grow rich too, if they take pains for it, and follow MerchandiÅ¿ing, and Å¿ome are actaually grown rich Å¿ince they came here, who had nothing before; if any Å¿hal miÅ¿credit what I have Å¿aid, I Å¿hall not think my Å¿elf baffled for that; but let them live in their opinion and I will live in mine. And if they pleaÅ¿e they may do with me as I did with John Skeens Wife, caÅ¿t my Letters in mine own teeth, and when
they come upon the place, I Å¿hall make good what I Å¿ay, face to face, as Å¿he did to me, and if they come not themÅ¿elves, they need not trouble themÅ¿elves whither it be true or falÅ¿e. The goods fit for this Countrey are all kind of houÅ¿e-hold PleniÅ¿hing, without which and a years proviÅ¿ion in victualls, let none come hither; if they would wiÅ¿h not to be preyed on by the old Planters. All courÅ¿e cloath Å¿uch as hodden-grayes, and Playding, courÅ¿e Stock â¢ ns and Linning, no fine things, for an infant Countrey, except for a mans own uÅ¿e; courÅ¿e Bedding and Blankets; Governour Barclay can give you full information as to this point. The Inconveninencies we have met with are, great trouble and charges for want of our baggadge; there is likewiÅ¿e trouble and charges in the firÅ¿t Å¿etlement, in carting out ones goods to the woods; fencing is the cheif Difficulty, and if the â¢ e be many great trees the logges moÅ¿t be drawn off with oxen and the branches burned, the trees are falled equal to a mans thigh hight, but the roots are no impediments, where is much bruÅ¿h the roots moÅ¿t be plucked up with grubbing howes; any man may learn Husbandries here, who was not aquaint with it in Scotland, (Tobacco would grow here as well as in Maryland, but it is
beÅ¿t for European graines; I doe not intend, to write more Letters to Edinburgh with this occaÅ¿ion; being buÅ¿ied about mine own Å¿etlement, therefore I intreat you will remember me to all my friends, Relations, Comarads, and Acquaintances at Edinburgh; and Å¿hew them of my wellfair that I had not my health Å¿o well this 7. years bygone, as now (BleÅ¿Å¿ed be God) and that I am not troubled here with coughs, and head aikes as in Edinburgh, which is likewiÅ¿e a great motive for me, to Å¿tay in this Countrey. I intreat to hear from them all, you will not readily miÅ¿s occaÅ¿ions from London every Moneth, to Å¿ome place in America; And there is ordinarly occaÅ¿ions hither from the Neighbour Collonies; I have received Letters from the BiÅ¿Å¿ets, and my Brother, from Mr. Alexander Å¿ince we came; I intreat to hear particularly from the ProfeÅ¿Å¿or of Divinitie, and Mathematicks, Doctor Pitcairn, Mr. George Burnet, Richard Maitland, Mr. George Alexander, and any others who Å¿hall ask for me, wiÅ¿hing you and all your concerns well,

closer.signed: Your moÅ¿t affectionate CuÅ¿in, and humble Servant, Charles Gordon.

div.head: P Å¿tÅ¿cript by the foreÅ¿aid hand.
div.p:
If any pleaÅ¿es to tell me what their Å¿cruples are, I Å¿hall endeavour to anÅ¿wer them, if Servants knew what a Countrey this is for them, and that they may live like little Lairds here; I think they would not be Å¿o Shey as they are to come, and during their Å¿ervice they are better uÅ¿ed then in any place in America I have Å¿een; you may know my SubÅ¿cription by the Å¿ign I gave you of my PiÅ¿toles miÅ¿Å¿erving in the Boat, or at leaÅ¿t when you tell your Mother, you may mind on me, for you will miÅ¿s Å¿ome pints of wine you Å¿pent with me, (that Fridays night, you convoyed me aboard) on the Shore, and in the Ship. If there were a Caball of Merchants here to export the product of the Countrey to Barbadoes, and the WeÅ¿t-Indies, and to Import Rumm, MalaÅ¿Å¿es, Suggar and Cotton, &c. it would do a great deal of good to this Countrey. I intreat to know what remarkable Revolutions has hapned either abroad or at home Å¿ince I came away. Any Merchants who Å¿ettles
here muÅ¿t take Lotts in the Town, and build houÅ¿es. Mr. David Mudie is building a Å¿tone houÅ¿e, and hath already an HorÅ¿e-mill ready to Å¿et up preÅ¿ently in New-Perth. Adue.

div.head: For Mr. James Mudie Merchant in MontroÅ¿e.
div.p:
MY Love ever being remembered to your Å¿elf, Lady and Children, theÅ¿e are earneÅ¿tly intreating you to let my Wife have any little thing Å¿he Å¿tands in need of untill it Å¿hall pleaÅ¿e the Lord I return; and I Å¿hall pay you very thankfully; I have left Thomas ParÅ¿on, and reÅ¿olves to trade this Summer in the Countrey, and to come home with your Uncle the nixt Spring. I wiÅ¿h you were here and your whole Family, for I doubt not but the Countrey would pleaÅ¿e you well; For there is abundance of much better Land here then ever Arbikie was, and an Earldome to be bought far below in pryce the vallow, of what Å¿uch pettie LairdÅ¿hipps as Arbikie is Å¿old for in Scotland; without purging of the Lands of any incumbrances; For I
hope to winn as much monie this year, as will buy a better LairdÅ¿hip then Arbikie; and if ye reÅ¿olve not to come over, I reÅ¿olve to buy Land before I come from this, and title it Arbikie. But I Å¿hall be Å¿orie to take away your title, for if I do, it will be your own fault; and for your better incouradgement I know you love a Gunn and a Dogge, and here ye will have uÅ¿e for both, For Wilde GeeÅ¿e, Turkies, Ducks, and Drake, Partridge, Cunies, Doves and innumerable more kind of Fowls which I know not their names, are here to be Å¿een every hour of the day, in flocks above ThouÅ¿ands in Number; And for your Skieft which you uÅ¿e to FiÅ¿h with; bring here with you, or one like her, for I aÅ¿Å¿ure you of good employment, and yet ye may catch more FiÅ¿h in an hour here, than any FiÅ¿her in MontroÅ¿e in two, excepting Podloes at the Å¿hore head.

Sir, take this as no jeÅ¿t from me, for what is here written is a reall truth; but ye may think, it is not my dictating, but the Writter and I have Å¿et it together the beÅ¿t way we can; But yet not Å¿o
full as I would have had it; PreÅ¿ent my Love to your SiÅ¿ter, Uncle, and all Friends, and I am,

closer.signed: Your very loving Friend and CuÅ¿in, James Mudie.

div.head: A Letter from David Mudie, Merchant in MontroÅ¿e: For James Mudie of Courthill in Scotland.
div.p:
I Write you a lyne upon my arivall here, and by my laÅ¿t to my Wife, of the date the 12. December, I deÅ¿ired her to let you Å¿ee it, which I hope Å¿he has done if it be come to her hands; I do now underÅ¿tand this Countrie, better then I did at that time, and the longer I travell in it I like it the better; for a frugall man with a Å¿mall fortune may very Å¿oon raiÅ¿e a good EÅ¿tate, which I wrote formerly to my Wife, in relation to the Countrie; I find it moÅ¿t certain and much better then I wrote; this Winter hath been exceeding hard and Å¿harpe, the like not Å¿een by thoÅ¿e who have lived 20. or 30. years in it, which hath
hindred me of a great deal of work; yet I have cleared three Acres of Ground to be an Orchard and a Garden, which lyes cloÅ¿e to the houÅ¿e which I am a building, which is all of Stone work, with Cellars under the Ground, Å¿ix Rooms off a floor, two Stories high, beÅ¿ide the Garrat; and I have two MaÅ¿Å¿ons dayly working at it Å¿ince the firÅ¿t of February; three Wrights working at an HorÅ¿e mill, which will be clear againÅ¿t the later end of this Moneth: And I am told that the Mill will be worth 100. lib. a year, but I am Å¿ure Å¿he will be better then 50. of clear Money, for every Scotsboll of Wheat or Indian Corn payes here for grinding of it 2. Å¿hill: Ster: this houÅ¿e and mill Å¿tands me a great deal of Money, but there is none Å¿uch in this Countrey, nor ever was. I reÅ¿olve to go out to the Countrey to the Land which I have taken up, which is upon a place called the South River, which is 2 hours going from my own houÅ¿e by water; I mind to Å¿ettle Å¿ome of my Servants there againÅ¿t the midle of this Moneth; I am provided with Å¿ix courÅ¿e HorÅ¿e, Oxen and Swine Å¿ufficiently in number, for any Plantation for the firÅ¿t year; the Land I have Å¿ettled on, in my Judgement is extroardinary good; If any Friend or Acquaintance hath any inclination to
come over here, I can aÅ¿Å¿ure them if they be Frugall men, and have but 300. lib. Ster: Stock, they may live better then a Gentleman with us of 40. Chalders of Victuall: I cannot now reÅ¿olve to come home till this time twelve Moneth, Å¿ince Thomas ParÅ¿on hath Å¿o much diÅ¿appointed me, as I have written to my wife; but againÅ¿t that time, if the LORD preÅ¿erve me in health, I will come home then; preÅ¿ent my Å¿ervice to Arbikie, and to my SiÅ¿ters, and to all our Friends; which will Å¿ave me a trouble to give them a Line, my love to your wife, and children, I am,

postscript.p: Let Arbikie, my SiÅ¿ters, and the reÅ¿t of my Friends, Å¿ee this Letter.

div.head: AbÅ¿tract of a Letter from Robert Fullerron, Brother to the Laird of Kinnaber, to his Brothers and SiÅ¿ters, from Amboy, the 6. of November, 1684.
div.p:
By the Mercies of the MoÅ¿t High, we are Å¿afe arryved, after a long Demur by
contrary winds, we encountered very hapily at firÅ¿t with Long IÅ¿land, and the next day came to an Anchor in New JerÅ¿ey; The PaÅ¿Å¿engers did all very well, though we had Å¿ome very rough guÅ¿ts, and were very throng in Å¿o Å¿mall a veÅ¿Å¿hel, being 130. Souls, beÅ¿ids Sea men, of theÅ¿e 27. were women, 6. or 7. children only; one man whom I hyred in your houÅ¿e, called William Clark Å¿tanding carleÅ¿ly upon the ForcaÅ¿tle tumbled over boards, and drowned tho we put out our boat and endeavoured in vain to Å¿ave him. This Countrey pleaÅ¿eth us very well, and appears to be nothing Å¿hort of our expectation; We were yeÅ¿terday ranging about veiwing our Land, where â¢
â¢ u Å¿hall have accompt by the next; ãâã Land in general is good, and a â¢ ree â¢
â¢â¢ th the accompt you have heard; t â¢â¢ I â¢ ees are no hing Å¿o invincible as I did â¢ magine, being neither Å¿o thick nor Å¿o great as we thought. The firÅ¿t plant which I touched was wild Bayes, which row in abundance here, the fruits are gery excellent, Å¿uch Å¿orts as I have Å¿een, v â¢ les the beÅ¿t I believe in the world, Å¿ome I have Å¿een of a pound weight;
Cattle in generall are abundantly plentifull, eÅ¿pecially HorÅ¿e and Oxen, the greatneÅ¿s and fatneÅ¿s of the Oxen will Countervail the Difference of the price, being about 5. lib. Å¿terling. The Countrey is not altogether leavell, as Å¿ome other Countries here, but hath eaÅ¿ie ryÅ¿ings, and Vallies; my new experience cannot give you Å¿uch an accompt as you may afterwards expect; but in generall the Countrey may Å¿atisfie any rationall ingenuous mind; yet I find there be Novices who knows no happineÅ¿s Å¿ave home, with a glaÅ¿s of Wine, and Comorads in a change HouÅ¿e; tho there be no want here of more noble devertiÅ¿ments as hunting wild BeaÅ¿ts, wild HorÅ¿es, and Deer; yeÅ¿terday I did Å¿ee Å¿everall droves of Deer, and wild HorÅ¿es, as I did ride up in the Countrey. The Land which we were veiwing is a large plain, under the blew hills, watered with two or three little Rivers about 8. or 9. miles from New-Perth, four from Rariton-River Northward; the land downwards is all taken up by the Quitrenters of PiÅ¿catway, Woodbridge, or Elizabeth Town; there Å¿hall be nothing of care wanting in
your affairs, and I do expect the like from you; I hope my Grand Mother is in health, wiÅ¿h her from me long life, and good health, and aÅ¿Å¿ure her, Å¿he wronged the Countrey in her opinion; preÅ¿ent my love to all my Friends, I am,

div.head: A Letter from John Forbes Brother to the Laird of Barnla. Directed to Mr. James ElphingÅ¿ton of Logie Writter to His MajeÅ¿ties Signet, in Edinburgh, in Scotland.

opener.dateline: From Amboy-point, alias New-Perth, in the Province of EaÅ¿t-New JerÅ¿ey, in America, March 18. 1685.

div.p:
I having the occaÅ¿ion of this Bearer Mr. Drummond, brother to John Drummond the Factor in Edinburgh, and who came PaÅ¿Å¿enger with me to this place from Scotland; I could not omit my duty in acquainting you by
this line, of our Å¿afe arrival into America; tho being by the Divine Hand of Providence miraculouÅ¿l â¢ preÅ¿erved from the cruelty of the tempeÅ¿tuous Ocean, occaÅ¿ioned by a mighty Å¿torm of wind, (which happened upon the 12. day of September laÅ¿t) and which blew Å¿o tempeÅ¿tuouÅ¿ly, that in Å¿hort, it carried firÅ¿t away our BolÅ¿pret, and afterwards our whole three MaÅ¿ts, FlagÅ¿taff, and all by the board, before the Sailers were able to get them cut; it likewiÅ¿e took away the awning above our quarterdeck, and left not Å¿o much as an yard of a rope above our heads, all which was done in the Å¿pace of half an hour; We lay thus diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed like a pitiful Wrack all that night (we having loÅ¿t our MaÅ¿ts about 12. of the clock in the day) and two dayes thereafter at the mercie of the Waves, (which being like mountains occaÅ¿ioned by the great Å¿torm of wind,) without hopes of recovery, being then above 200. leagues from this land of America, toÅ¿Å¿ing to and fro, expecting that each wave Å¿hould overwhelm us; Yet at laÅ¿t it pleaÅ¿ed GOD to turn the Å¿torm into a calm; and having preÅ¿erved all our lower Yairds, we made all haÅ¿te and made Jury MaÅ¿ts of them; with the help whereof, (tho very unÅ¿ufficient ones, to dryve forward the bulk of Å¿o great a VeÅ¿Å¿el) and of
GODS miraculous Mercie and Providence; Who immediatly after we had put our Å¿hip in any mean poÅ¿ture for plying out her Voyage, was pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿end us Å¿uch a fair and moderate gale of wind, as brought us in Å¿ight of the Capes of Virginia, within 15. dayes after or there abouts, having never ceaÅ¿ed for the whole time, till it brought us thither in Å¿afty; So we came within the Capes, and Å¿ailed up that great Navigable Bay, called CheÅ¿Å¿apeik bay, up through all Virginia up to Maryland, where we landed at the place where our Å¿hip was bound to take in her Tobacco, for her homeward Loadning. But being this DiÅ¿abled, and not being able to ply out her Voyage to this place (where Å¿he ought to have landed us, we was neceÅ¿Å¿itat to travel from thence by Land to this place, being upwards of 200. EngliÅ¿h miles, and having left our Goods behind us, which was thereafter to come about in a Sloup) we was neceÅ¿Å¿itat to Å¿tay all Winter in this New and young Citie, where we had but very bad Commodation for Lodging, tho we knew of no want of Victuals of all Å¿orts for mony, tho at a conÅ¿iderable dear rate; This hindered us long from our falling to work about our husbandries, which was a great loÅ¿s of time to us. However when our Å¿loup came about,
(which did not hold the half of our goods; So that every man yet wants the half of his goods. But are dayly expecting them by the Å¿ame Sloup which we fraghted thither back again. I went out to the Woods to the land we had pitched upon, with Å¿everal others of our Counteey men, Å¿uch as Tho: Gordon, and Mr. Chat: his Brother, Brothers to the Laird of Straloch, Kinnabers two Sons, Robert and Mr. Thomas Fullertons, James JohnÅ¿ton of Spotswood, and John Barclay the Governours Brother, with Å¿ome others; where we have all pitched near by one another, upon an piece of excellent land as we Å¿uppoÅ¿e; Whereof I judge I have not the worÅ¿t, (if not the abÅ¿olute beÅ¿t piece of land in all that Tract, for we had it all at our own choiÅ¿ing and not by lots, this land lyes not on a Navigable River, but about 5. or 6. miles from Rariton river, which is Navigable up the neareÅ¿t place to our Plantations; For the beÅ¿t places of the Rivers are already inhabited by the old Planters of this Countrey who have been here Å¿ome 16. or 18. years agoe. There are many places upon Navigable Rivers yet untaken, and Å¿ome very near this place alÅ¿o, which is intended to be the Metrapolis of this Province; But it is generally Å¿andy barren land, and the beÅ¿t
land is compute by all to be in the woods, back Å¿ome Å¿everal miles from the Navigable Rivers; So that we rather chuÅ¿e land for profitablneÅ¿s, then for Conveniences of Towns, and pleaÅ¿ure allennarly. For there is aboundance both of good and barren land in this Province; So that a man may chuÅ¿e Å¿ome for pleaÅ¿ure, and Å¿ome for profit and Conveniency, for I intend to take up about 4. or 500. Acres where I have now Å¿etled; which is on a very pleaÅ¿ant place and good land, and whereof I have with two hands (not having had time to get many Servants away with me, having come away upon Å¿o Å¿hort advertiÅ¿ement, and whereof I loÅ¿t one at Maryland by Å¿ickneÅ¿s; Å¿o that now I have but two, and a Woman for dreÅ¿Å¿ing our Victuals and Cloaths, till I get more Å¿ent me this year) already cleared, or at leaÅ¿t will clear; and have in Corn this year about 8, or 10, Acres of ground; tho it was prettie thick of Å¿tately tale Timber, and that Å¿ince the 26. of January, at which time, I went to the Woods. I have 1000. Acres to take up at this time out of the firÅ¿t DiviÅ¿ion of 10000. Acres ordained to be laid out to every Proprietor; I having bought a 10. part, whereof my Brother is half Å¿harer. I have alÅ¿o taken up 400. Acres of excellent fine land on
Rariton River, about 20. miles above Amboy, whereon I deÅ¿ign to Å¿et Servants, that I expect over this enÅ¿uing Summer; and Å¿o to divide our Å¿aid parcels, and improve them for a year or two to the beÅ¿t advantage, and then to Å¿ell them off. If I deÅ¿ign to come home, which we can do at good profite. Now for a general deÅ¿cription of this Countrey, it is a fine place for thoÅ¿e who have a good Å¿tock, to lay out upon a Å¿tock of Cattel of all Å¿orts, which do greatly multiply here in a Å¿hort time, and are Å¿old at great rates, and may Å¿oon increaÅ¿e a Å¿tock greatly; or it is a good Countrey for an InduÅ¿trious Frugal Man, that deÅ¿ignes to follow Husbandries cloÅ¿lie; providing he bring but Å¿ome little Å¿tock to Å¿tock a Plantation withall; or it is very good for TradÅ¿men, as good Carpenters, Smiths, Tailors, &c. who will get large wages a day. But it is not a Countrey for idle Å¿luggiÅ¿h People; or thoÅ¿e who cannot Å¿ome times put too their hands, and encourage their Servants. It is a place that produces many fine Fruits, and PhyÅ¿ick Herbs; The Woods are Å¿tored with wild Deers, Conies, Woulves, Boars, Racouns, Å¿ome Bavers, and Å¿everal other BeaÅ¿ts, which have fine Furrs. There is alÅ¿o abundance of Fowls, and FiÅ¿h, and Water Fowl for the killing. The Timber
are moÅ¿tly Oak of all Å¿orts, Walnut, CheÅ¿nut, whereof there are great abundance where I have planted, tho they beÅ¿carce Å¿o bigg as theÅ¿e that comes to Scotland, yet large as pleaÅ¿ant. Strawberries grow very thick upon the ground amongÅ¿t the Trees; Å¿o that Å¿ome places of the Woods are in Summer as it were covered with a red cloath. As I am certainly informed, Fruit Trees advance at a great rate in this place, for a Man may have an Orchard within a few years after the Planting, that may yeeld him a great quantitie of Cydar, which is the chiefeÅ¿t of their drink in this Province, even amongÅ¿t the meaneÅ¿t of the Planters; So that this Countrey if well improved, may make a fine place; for Nature has been defficient in nothing to it, either for pleaÅ¿ure or fruitfulneÅ¿s of the Soyl; So that a man being once Å¿ettled two or three years in it, and having Corn, Cattle, and all things neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the uÅ¿e of man within himÅ¿elf. And the trouble and hardÅ¿hip of his firÅ¿t Å¿ettling by his hand; He may live as Comfortably here as in any place of the World; Providing he could diÅ¿pence with the want of his Friends and Relations, and the Å¿atisfacti â¢ n of their Companie, which is the loÅ¿s I moÅ¿t regrate in this place; And thus having given yon a Å¿hort deÅ¿cription of the place, I
cannot but in the next place, much regrate my misfortune, in not Å¿eeing you, and taking your adviÅ¿e before I came to this place; But my ReÅ¿olution was Å¿o Å¿udden, by the encouragement I received from the Chief Governour, and Å¿ome of the Proprietors at Aberdeen; and having come in onely to Å¿ee my SiÅ¿ter with my Brother; and by the many Gentlemen that were going along in the Å¿hip, that I was induced to go along without Å¿o much as taking my leave of any of my Friends, Å¿ave onely theÅ¿e that were then in Town; So that I came of reÅ¿olution only to Å¿ee the place, and to Å¿ettle onlie if I fand conveniency. And having thus abruptly come away, when I came here, I deÅ¿igned not to return till I took Å¿ome tryal of the Countrey, that at my return I might be the more able to give an true accompt thereof. I am not as yet of any determined reÅ¿olution as to my Å¿taying for altogether as yet; but I reÅ¿olved to Å¿tay this year, till I Å¿ee what the ground produces; and to Å¿ee how my endeavours take effect; and GOD willing, be that time, I may in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure be reÅ¿olved what to do, for then the greateÅ¿t hardÅ¿hip will be over my head; and by that time I will have up an prettie good houÅ¿e, which is near already framed; whereas hitherto I have dwelt for the moÅ¿t part here in a Wigwam,
(as we call them here) accounting all our hardÅ¿hip in the beginning but Å¿hort, in expectation of good Å¿ucceÅ¿s in the end. But however I may be reÅ¿olved hereafter, I intend GOD willing, life and health Å¿erving to come home a Å¿tart within this year or two, and Å¿ee all my Friends; and apollogize the beÅ¿t manner I can, for my abrupt departure. Now having thus in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure diÅ¿charged a part of my dutyfull reÅ¿pects towards you by this line, in letting you know of my welfare and preÅ¿ent condition; EarneÅ¿tly deÅ¿iring ye will favour me with a return by the firÅ¿t occaÅ¿ion; wherein I Å¿hall be glade to hear of your welfare, of your kind Ladies and Children (To whom and others my neareÅ¿t Freinds and Relations, and Comarads, I deÅ¿ire the favour to be Kindly remembered, begging pardon for this trouble, and your patience to peruÅ¿e this, when your leaÅ¿ure can permit; and afterwards to communicat it to my Æ²ncle, Calder-hall and his Lady, or to my CuÅ¿ins Harie Lockhart, or George Ersken, if they call for it; I not having time at preÅ¿ent to write to them at length, as I have in haÅ¿te done to you; I Å¿hall forbear to give you furder trouble at preÅ¿ent; intreating you to remember me kindly to your Worthy and Oblidging
Lady, and fine Children, and Å¿hall only Å¿ubÅ¿crive my Å¿elf, as I Å¿incerly am, and Å¿hall continue,

closer.signed: Your moÅ¿t affectionat CuÅ¿in, and oblidged Servant, while John Forbes.

div.head: A Leter from Thomas Fullertoun, to his Brother the Laird of Kinnaber, dated from his new poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, in the plains of new CaeÅ¿aria; January 7. 1685.
div.p:
YOu have above a tranÅ¿cript, containing the principal Contents of an abrupt Letter, Å¿ent you three or four days after our arrivall; Å¿ince that time we have poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed our Selves in the above mentioned plain 11. miles from New-Perth, four from Rariton Northward; And 12. from Elizabeth-Town; we have the honour to be the firÅ¿t Inland planters in this part of America, for the former Settlement have been by the River-Å¿ides, which are all poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed
by the Quit-renters; the which I would have grudged at, had I not found the goodneÅ¿s of the Land, upwards will countervaill the trouble of tranÅ¿portation to the water; As to the number and nature of theÅ¿e Quit-renters, they are about 2. or 300. Families, Å¿ome civill and DiÅ¿creet, others rude and Malcontent with the late PurchaÅ¿Å¿ers. and need Å¿ome thing of auÅ¿terity to make them ComplaiÅ¿ant; We have at preÅ¿ent Å¿harp froÅ¿ts, and a good deall of Snow, three dayes of vitrefying froÅ¿t, this winter, had not its match for cold theÅ¿e 16. years by gone, as the Inhabitants do inform us. AgainÅ¿t this extream we have a good Defence of Fire, and felling of Trees, and might live warm enough, were we not forced to travell for recruit of ProviÅ¿ions. I reckon the winter to conÅ¿iÅ¿t only of nights, for the Suns appearance by day moderateth the cold, and melts the FroÅ¿t; I do not find the cold here to cauÅ¿e obÅ¿tructions or coughs; the Air is ever transÅ¿parent; we have Å¿ingular good Å¿tomachs, which if it continue as they Å¿ay, it will require a fertile Countrey when peopled; the water
or temper of the Air keeps mens bellies moderatly looÅ¿s; I cannot find it neceÅ¿Å¿ar to give any particular account of this Country with its product, becauÅ¿e ye have had already many, and Å¿ome very ingenuous of this nature; beÅ¿ides I have not yet proof of all the Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the year; we have the Deer to walk the round nightly about our Lodge; this morning I Å¿hot a large Hart, and followed his bloody tract in the Å¿now, above two miles before he dyed; I believe the fateÅ¿t Deer in the world are here; we have made choiÅ¿e of your land next adjacent to mine, and have placed your Servants there, where they will Å¿ettle if we find convenient, when the Å¿now is away; this is all at preÅ¿ent from,

div.head: Another Letter from the Å¿ame hand, dated the 10. of March 1685.
AbÅ¿tract of a Letter from Charles Gordon, (Brother to the Laird of Straloch,) to Doctor John Gordon, Doctor of Medicine at MontroÅ¿e; dated at Woodbridge, in EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey, 7. of March, 1685.
div.p:
I DeÅ¿ign 100. pound Sterling for goods and Å¿ervants, if TradÅ¿e-men and Servants knew they were better uÅ¿ed here then in any Neighbouring Collonie, and that after their time is expired, they may gain a Å¿tock by their work, and live like Å¿ome of your Lairds before they dye; they would not Å¿o much Å¿crouple to come hither. There are a number of queries propoÅ¿ed by our Brother
Thomas to the Fullertouns, which I remember you deÅ¿ired me to anÅ¿wear, the moÅ¿t matteriall of them are anÅ¿wered, by this and my former Letters; I Å¿hall therefore Å¿uperceed any long deÅ¿cription of it, till I Å¿ee it throw all the Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the year; in Å¿hort, I Å¿ee it pleaÅ¿ant, and furniÅ¿hed with all conveniencies of Nature, Å¿uch as woods, graÅ¿s, meadow; plenty of FreÅ¿h Springs, Creeks, and Rivers; I find it wholeÅ¿ome, for I am not (bleÅ¿Å¿ed be God) troubled here with Defluction, headakes, and coughs as at Edinburgh, which is a great inducement for me or any valitudinary man to Å¿tay in this Countrey: People come from Barbadoes, to York, and hither for their healths Å¿ake; if you deÅ¿ign to come hither your Å¿elf, you may come as a Planter, or a Merchant, but as a Doctor of Medicine I cannot adviÅ¿e you; for I can hear of no deÅ¿eaÅ¿es here to cure but Å¿ome Agues, and Å¿ome cutted legs and fingers; and there are no want of Empericks for theÅ¿e already; I confeÅ¿s you could doe more then any yet in America, being verÅ¿ed both in Chirurgery, Pharmacie; for here are abundance of
curious Herbs, Shrubs, and Trees; and no doubt Mediciniall ones for making of drogs; but there is little or no Imployment this way; your Servants are Å¿etled on a pleaÅ¿ant plain beÅ¿ide the Fullertouns on a brook, called The Vine or Ceder Brooks; from a Å¿wamp of Cedars, from whence it Springs, and the multiplicity of Vines which grow upon it; all your friends and Countrey men here are in good health, bleÅ¿Å¿ed be GOD; This hath been the hardeÅ¿t Winter that was almoÅ¿t Å¿ince ever there were EngliÅ¿h here. The Å¿ound betwixt JerÅ¿ey and Staten-IÅ¿land was frozen in January, that carts and horÅ¿e went upon it; betwixt Martinmas and ChriÅ¿tmas flying Å¿hours of Å¿now with clear moderat froÅ¿ts; in January deep Å¿now and moÅ¿t bitter froÅ¿ts, which ever I found, but did no wayes affect peoples bodies; the Air being ordinar clear and Å¿erene; about the 20. of January, the Å¿now went off inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly; and about 3. weeks in February, it was almoÅ¿t like Summer in Scotland; the end of February and beginning of March for the moÅ¿t part rain and wind; Acquaint me the value of Å¿weet-Å¿ent-Gumm,
which flowes from the wood-Gum-trees of SaÅ¿Å¿afras, SaÅ¿Å¿apatella, and Å¿uch other things as the Countrey naturally produceth; Be pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿end me Å¿ome Medicins for Agues, and accidentall cutts, or Å¿ores, in caÅ¿e my Å¿elf or Servants be overtaken with them; I hope with the bleÅ¿Å¿ing of GOD, here to make a livlihood for my Å¿elf; I intreat to hear what remarkable news, and revolutions are either at home with you, or abroad, and Å¿o continues,

div.head: A Letter from Thomas Gordon Brother to the Laird of Straloch. For Mr. George Alexander Advocat, in Edinburgh.

opener.dateline: From the Cedar-Brook of EaÅ¿t-New-JerÅ¿ey in America, the 16. February, 1685.

div.p:
THis is the fifth time I have written to you Å¿ince I came to America, Å¿ome of which I am confident have
come Å¿afe to your hands; Å¿o that I need not now reÅ¿ume them, for in them I gave you a full account of our danger by Sea, and travels by Land; and therefore I Å¿hall now proceed and begin where I left laÅ¿t, upon the eighteen day of November I and my Servants came here to the Woods, and 8. dayes thereafter my Wife and Children came alÅ¿o; I put up a Wigwam in 24. hours, which Å¿erved us till we put up a better houÅ¿e, which I made 24. foot long, and 15. foot wide, containing a Hall and Citchen both in one, and a Chamber and a Study, which we put up pretty well (with PalliÅ¿adoes on the Å¿ides, and Shingles on the roof) againÅ¿t Yuill, on which day we entred home to it, and have been ever Å¿ince, and Å¿till am clearing ground, & making fencing; So that I hope to have as much ground, cleared, fenced, ploughed, and planted with Indian Corn in the beginning of May, (which is the beÅ¿t time for planting it) as will maintain my Family the next year, if it pleaÅ¿e GOD to proÅ¿per it; Robert Fullertoun and I are to joyn for a Plough this Spring, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of 4. Oxen and two HorÅ¿e, but if the Ground were once broken up, two Oxen and two HorÅ¿e, or 4. Oxen alone, will Å¿erve; Å¿o that the next Å¿pring I intend (GOD willing)
to have a Plough of my own alone; I intend to build a better HouÅ¿e and larger, and to make a Kitchen of this I am in; which I will hardly get done this Summer, becauÅ¿e I reÅ¿olve to build upon my lot at New-Perth; I am Å¿ettled here in a very pleaÅ¿ant place, upon the Å¿ide of a brave plain (almoÅ¿t free of woods) and near the water Å¿ide, Å¿o that I might yoke a Plough where I pleaÅ¿e, were it not for want of Hay to maintain the Cattle which I hope to get helped the next year, for I have Å¿everal pieces of Meadow near me. The firÅ¿t Snow we had was about the midÅ¿t of November, & went twice away again, and about the end of the Moneth it came on, and continued with very great FroÅ¿t and knee deep Snow till towards the end of January; And then the Snow diÅ¿Å¿olved pleaÅ¿antly and calmly with the heat and influence of the Sun, and now I judge it as warm here as it will be with you in May, and much more pleaÅ¿ant, for we are not by far Å¿o much troubled with winds here as ye are in Scotland; the winter was generall very pleaÅ¿ant and calm, altho Å¿ometimes very vehement froÅ¿t; I have Å¿poken with Å¿everal old Inhabitants here, who aÅ¿Å¿ure me they had not Å¿een Å¿o hard a winter as this has been theÅ¿e 16 years bygone; and truely
if I never Å¿ee much worÅ¿e I Å¿hall be very well pleaÅ¿ed with this Countrie; we have great abundance of Deer, Turkies, &c. here about us; and as for the wild BeaÅ¿ts, and Natives (whereof I was greatly affrayed before I came here) I find no danger, trouble, inconveniency thereby at all; there are abundance of all Å¿orts of Cattle in this Countrey to be had at very reaÅ¿onable rates, I can buy a good Cow for 4 lib. Å¿ter. a good Ox for 5. lib. Å¿ter. and a good HorÅ¿e for 5, or 6. lib. Å¿ter. a Hogg for 20. Å¿s. Å¿ter. a BuÅ¿hell of Wheat for 4. Å¿s. Å¿ter. of Rye 3. Å¿s. 6. d. Å¿ter. of Indian Corn for 2. Å¿s. 6. d. Å¿ter. There are 8. of us Å¿ettled here within half a mile, or a mile of another, and about ten miles from the Town of New-Perth, or Amboy-point, Å¿o that I can go and come in a day either on foot or horÅ¿eback. viz. Robert and Thomas Fullertouns, James JohnÅ¿toun of SpotÅ¿wood, John Forbes, John Barclay, Doctor John Gordon his Servants, Andrew Alexander, and my Self; this is the moÅ¿t of what I can Å¿ay of this Countrey at preÅ¿ent, for I intend to write nothing but what I either Å¿ee or know to be certainly true, and for my part I am very well pleaÅ¿ed with this retired Countrey life; and I love this Countrey very well as yet; altho I hear of
Å¿ome of our Countrey men who are not, neither can it be expected, that any Countrey in the World will pleaÅ¿e the different humours of all PerÅ¿ons; bleÅ¿Å¿ed be GOD, my Å¿elf and Wife and Children and Å¿ervants have been and are Å¿till in good health which GOD continue; be pleaÅ¿ed to communicate this to both yours, and my Friends and Acquaintances, becauÅ¿e I have not leaÅ¿ure to writ at great length to every one; and let theÅ¿e remember me to all others that give themÅ¿elves the trouble to inquire for,

closer.signed: Your moÅ¿t humble and and oblidged Servant, Thomas Gordon.

div.head: A Letter from David Mudie of the date of the former, to Mr. Alexander Gairns, one of the MiniÅ¿ters at Edinburgh.
div.p:
I Did write to you a line upon my arrival here, and my laÅ¿t the 12. of December, directed to John Graham, I deÅ¿ired him to let you Å¿ee his letter, and my wifes, which would inform you

div.head: A Letter from Thomas Fullertoun, Brother to the Laird of Kinnaber, to John JohnÅ¿toun DroguÅ¿t, in Edinburgh, dated the 9. of March, 1685. from EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey.
div.p:
YOur Brother and I did write to you about three Moneths agoe, wherein we told you, that we were 9. weeks at Å¿ea, after we parted from Killebegs in Ireland, we were all very well; at Sea only we had more Stomachs then meat, to prevent which, if you or any other Commorad come this way, it will be prudence to fortifie themÅ¿elves with good CheeÅ¿e, Butter, Bisket, Caks, and Brandie; I believe you are cloyed with deÅ¿criptions of the Countrey; And therefore this in brief, the reports you hear of it are generally true, Å¿ome it may be are Hyperbolick in magnifying its GoodneÅ¿s, but as many are detractive from what it really deÅ¿erves; There is abundance of good Land for the improving; Abundance of Swine and Cattle for the raiÅ¿ing, Deers for killing, houÅ¿es for the building: But Å¿ome expect all
theÅ¿e without pains. Your brother and I and our Servants have had good VeniÅ¿on broth once a day, all this winter; to be Å¿hort, if a man pleaÅ¿e to live a Countrey Life to labour Land, plant Orchards, and Å¿uch like; I believe he cannot come to a place that will better anÅ¿wer his expectations, and when he hath a minde to be merry he will get a PunÅ¿h-houÅ¿e, and very good fellows. I hope in a little time I Å¿hall want nothing but the company of the prettie Girls, to all whom, who retain any remembrance of me, Let my Å¿ervice be remembered, & to all friends; I long exceedingly to hear from you, but more to Å¿ee you; we had many difficulties as our entrance, and in our firÅ¿t indeavours; But when you come, I hope they Å¿hall be prevented by,

div.head: A Letter from James JohnÅ¿toun of SpotÅ¿wood, to Alexander HenderÅ¿on writter in Edinburgh; dated the 9. of March, 1685. from his Plantation at the blew Hills in EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey in America.
div.p:
THeÅ¿e are to preÅ¿ent my beÅ¿t wiÅ¿hes to you, and all Acquaintances, if any injoyment could make up the want of your Company, I Å¿hould not complain here; what elÅ¿e can contribute to profite or pleaÅ¿ure, being here to be had; neither is there any thing here to diÅ¿courage us; Quakers are not numerous; Wolves are Å¿o far from troubling men, that if a man Å¿hall lay a Glove upon a CarcaÅ¿s, or their prey, they will yell, but not come nigh it: You cannot come nigh a rattle-Snake, but they will rattle with their taile: whereby a man is advertiÅ¿ed either to kill them, or go by them; they frequently charm Squirrels, or other little BeaÅ¿ts of the tops of the Trees unto their mouth, and that without touching them with their teeth; which if they did, they would
poiÅ¿on themÅ¿elves. There is a Flee by the Å¿alt MariÅ¿hes moÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome in Summer, but is not in the up-lands; I am mightily well Å¿atisfied with my coming over, neither do I think I could live again in Scotland. In the Summer there is plenty of Fruits, Peaches, Walnuts, CheÅ¿nuts, Strawberries, and another berry like Currans; Vines as good as any where. I and all who have come over, have kept our health very well; our food hath for the moÅ¿t part been VeniÅ¿on; we got from the Indians which I like exceeding well. The Indian Corn, Indian Beans, and PeaÅ¿e, are pleaÅ¿ant Grains; we have very good fiÅ¿hing; preÅ¿ent my Å¿ervice to all Friends, and believe me to be ever,

I Nothing queÅ¿tion but by the peruÅ¿all of the above written Letters, you are abundantly Å¿atisfied, that EaÅ¿t-JerÅ¿ey as to all things neceÅ¿Å¿ar will accommodat our preÅ¿ent deÅ¿ign; But if Å¿ome (Malevolent PerÅ¿ons) who becauÅ¿e
